You may not notice the difference in your cellphone conversations or the look of Internet content on your computer screens. But fundamental changes taking place in many of the structural components of telecom networks is flashing some positive signals — and raising critical challenges — for makers of fiber-optic telecom gear. The changes come with labels like NFV, SDN, 100G…

Hewlett-Packard showed some muscle in the fledgling Network Functions Virtualization market by beating Cisco Systems, VMware and others in signing telecom carrier Telefonica to a multiyear pact.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is one of several tech giants scrambling to offer NFV, a virtualization computing system that relies more on software than hardware to help service providers speed an increasing amount of data through their networks at a reduced cost.Besides Cisco Systems (CSCO) and VMware (VMW), other NFV providers include Juniper Networks (JNPR).HP will fuel Telefonica's Unica project. Telefonica is moving all of its services, including Internet and mobile, to a new platform driven by NFV and software-defined networking, another technology system where software presides over hardware. The project will take several years.Spain-based Telefonica (TEF) is a large telecom operating in 21 countries, mostly in Europe and Latin America.HP is stepping up its NFV efforts, launched only last year, as the company gets closer to splitting into two separate companies. One will focus on PCs and printers, the other on enterprise products and services.Signing Telefonica should boost HP's revenue and set a bar for rivals in the NFV market, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC."It's a nice win in advance of the split," Del Prete told IBD. "Carriers are going to be moving more toward these network functions and virtualization environments. This is a big industry shift that is going to be measured in billions."UBS on Tuesday upgraded HP to buy from neutral and hiked its 12-month price target to 40 from 37.25. HP stock is trading near 33. In a research report, UBS analyst Steve Milunovich said, "(HP Enterprise is) too hardware-dependent but improving. Software and services need to pick up, or HP Enterprise might be forced to merge with another larger computing vendor."With the Telefonica contract, HP has seemingly leapfrogged rivals in what looks to be a very large market, says Roz Roseboro, an analyst for Heavy Reading, a market research firm that focuses solely on the telecom market."From an endorsement standpoint, it's very big," she told IBD. "The market right now is very much up in the air in terms of who is going to end up in the lead position with all of this NFV transformation."HP provides NFV services for several customers, but Telefonica is a milestone for the company, says Saar Gillai, general manager of HP's NFV program."This is our biggest deal in terms of providing end-to-end capabilities across our entire portfolio with open NFV," he told IBD.Not all of HP's rivals can handle such a large NFV migration, Gillai says."We are uniquely positioned in this space because a lot of the traditional vendors are playing defense — they have a lot of existing systems that are in the old architecture, and they are not necessarily that motivated to get the new architecture that quickly," he said.Other vendors, such as Cisco, are stepping up their efforts in the NFV and SDN markets, said Amitabh Passi, an analyst for UBS Securities, in a March 2 research report."Unlike years past, Cisco is more openly embracing shifts to software defined networking and Network Functions Virtualization, and in fact accelerating the shift to software and cloud services," he wrote.Several other telecom carriers, including AT&T (T) and Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), are in the process of adopting NFV.Reducing costs and streamlining networks are top priorities, says Roseboro."They are moving from a world where you have lots of different boxes that are specialized to do one thing and moving all of that onto more commodity servers, which allows you to lower your capex," she said. "And once it's virtualized, you can start using some other kind of IT tools to automate a lot of your processes and reduce your opex quite significantly."Gillai declined to put a value on the Telefonica contract."I can say that it's meaningful revenue, and it's also an indicator of things to come," he said.HP's revenue needs a boost. In the quarter ended Jan. 31, its enterprise revenue was flat with the year-earlier quarter, at $6.98 billion. And its enterprise services revenue fell 11% to $4.99 billion.
Palo Alto Networks, a leading stock pick, has vaulted higher as it puts a patent dispute to bed and as analysts see its security products in demand at data centers.
Known for network firewalls and other corporate security offerings, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) makes the IBD Leaderboard list of high-potential stocks. On Monday, it pushed up more than 3% to 83.85.

"PANW remains a top pick for 2014, our favorite play on the secular trend toward consolidated network-security functionality," Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss wrote in an early-Monday research note boosting his price target to 105.

Weiss says several factors, including corporate security purchasing plans, bolster his confidence that the company can sustain 30% or better billings growth in fiscal 2015. He also notes that the company will see slower growth in capital expenditures and a reduction in litigation expenses.

Palo Alto Networks offers a next-generation network-security platform used by enterprises, service providers and government entities to protect their networks from viruses, malware and other threats. Its lineup includes network firewall software and hardware. It also sells subscription services for threat detection and prevention, web filtering and mobile device security.
Patent Issue Past

Palo Alto Networks stock is up 46% this year and 21% since the firm announced the end of a legal saga May 28 and released third-quarter fiscal 2014 results. They topped estimates with 49% year-over-year revenue growth to $150.7 million, and 57% earnings growth to 11 cents a share.

"These results were driven by continued strong product demand, robust service growth and a rapid market-share gain in the large and growing strategic enterprise security market," CEO Mark McLaughlin said on a call with analysts at the time, noting the firm had "settled all existing litigation with Juniper."

Palo Alto Networks paid $175 million to settle a suit in which Juniper Networks (JNPR) claimed that Palo Alto Networks products infringed on six of its patents. Under terms of the deal, Palo Alto Networks agreed to make a one-time payment of $75 million in cash and pay $100 million in shares of common stock and warrants to buy common stock.

Juniper Networks filed the suit in December 2011. Palo Alto Networks later accused the company of infringing on three of its patents. As part of the settlement, the two firms agreed to license the patents at issue to each other and not file infringement suits for the next eight years.

"As we said from the beginning of this case, we do not believe that we infringed on any Juniper patents, and we still believe this to be the case," McLaughlin said on the Q3 call. "However, over the course of the last 2-1/2 years, we've spent a large amount of time, money and other resources on this litigation. ... We believe that this outcome will allow us to continue to focus our efforts in what we do best: innovating and developing new products, servicing our customers and the growth that results from that."

Although $175 million is a hefty sum for a company with less than $400 million in revenue as recently as its last fiscal year, the settlement did remove "a key overhang" on Palo Alto Networks stock, says FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi.
Stock Sets New High
With the overhang gone, Palo Alto Networks stock, which debuted in an IPO two years ago, hit a record high of 82.27 on June 17 and then passed that by almost 2% Monday.
The settlement is also seen resolving hesitancy on the part of some customers to do business with Palo Alto Networks as long as the lawsuit was up in the air.
"With this removal, we think Palo Alto can experience incrementally more sales," Seyrafi noted.

Palo Alto Networks seeks to continue expanding an operation that already includes 16,000-plus customers in more than 120 countries across multiple industries. One potential growth area is in the enterprise market, where it looks to win business with a next-generation security firewall designed for corporate data centers.
Guard For Data Centers

Palo Alto Networks' new PA-7050 security appliance will help it gain market share in the enterprise market, analysts predict. The product, launched in February, provides up to 120 gigabits per second of throughput speed to analyze threats to corporate data centers.

"Palo Alto has plenty of room left to take share in enterprise network security," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Rob Owens wrote in a report. "Data-center deployments account for over 30% of Palo Alto's product revenue, and the release of the PA-7050 appliance expands the opportunity into even higher-performance environments."

Meanwhile, analysts praise Palo Alto Networks' ability to win new business in a competitive field that includes pure plays such as Juniper, Symantec (SYMC) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), plus broader hardware and software firms such as Cisco Systems (CSCO).

"Palo Alto is the clear market leader and is defining the market in the next-generation firewall space," Citi Investment Research analyst Walter Pritchard noted. "With clear differentiation and technology leadership, we see continued share gains ahead for Palo Alto."

Among factors working for Palo Alto Networks' potential, Morgan Stanley analyst Weiss notes that 43% of corporate security executives polled plan a firewall refresh (upgrades and replacements) this year vs. 23% last year. And with only 10% using Palo Alto for their primary firewall and/or unified threat-management needs now, he sees room for market share gains.
Weiss says the company has strong positioning and an improving margin trend past fiscal 2015.
More Acquisitions Ahead?

As Palo Alto Networks gains size, it may also eye more buyouts as a way to expand its piece of the pie, analysts say. The firm has not made a huge number of deals through the years, though it has made a couple in 2014. In January, it acquired Morta Security, a Silicon Valley-based cybersecurity company, for an undisclosed sum. In April, it completed its $200 million buyout of Cyvera, a privately held cybersecurity company in Tel Aviv, Israel.

Palo Alto Networks might be set for more acquisitions after its recent decision to issue $500 million of convertible senior notes due in 2019. In a research note, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said Palo Alto intends to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, which include working capital, capital expenditures, potential acquisitions and strategic transactions.

"We believe the funds from the convertible offering would provide the company with significant latitude to further broaden its technology and next-generation security-solution suite, as it did with its recent acquisition of Cyvera to enter the endpoint-protection space in what we view to be a very positive fashion," Ho said.
A Palo Alto Networks spokeswoman said no company officials were available to speak for this story.

Financially, Palo Alto Networks continues showing robust growth, notching year-over-year revenue gains of at least 46% each quarter since going public. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 40 cents for fiscal 2014, which ends in July, up from 21 cents last year. Fiscal 2015 earnings are seen rising 65% to 66 cents a share.Palo Alto Networks, a leading stock pick, has vaulted higher as it puts a patent dispute to bed and as analysts see its security products in demand at data centers.Known for network firewalls and other corporate security offerings, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) makes the IBD Leaderboard list of high-potential stocks. In a research note, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said Palo Alto intends to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, which include working capital, capital expenditures, potential acquisitions and strategic transactions."We believe the funds from the convertible offering would provide the company with significant latitude to further broaden its technology and next-generation security-solution suite, as it did with its recent acquisition of Cyvera to enter the endpoint-protection space in what we view to be a very positive fashion," Ho said.A Palo Alto Networks spokeswoman said no company officials were available to speak for this story.Financially, Palo Alto Networks continues showing robust growth, notching year-over-year revenue gains of at least 46% each quarter since going public. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 40 cents for fiscal 2014, which ends in July, up from 21 cents last year. Fiscal 2015 earnings are seen rising 65% to 66 cents a share.

In its "Global Application & Network Security Report" for 2014-15, Radware called 2014 "a watershed year" for the cybersecurity industry, one in which cyberattacks "reached a tipping point" in terms of their quantity, length, complexity and targets.Radware (RDWR) should know. It provides integrated application delivery and network security hardware for enterprises ranging from banks and insurers to manufacturers, retailers, telecoms, government agencies, media firms and service providers.The company's core product provides load balancing, traffic management, application performance monitoring and network security. Its website boasts that it offers "complete security of business critical applications" for around 10,000 enterprises and carriers worldwide. Its partners include Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).In addition to helping businesses improve productivity and profitability, and lower IT operating and infrastructure costs, Radware's cybersecurity and application delivery solutions are designed to help customers secure and manage network traffic.Safety Is SellingThe security end of the business has become "a very hot market" for Radware, says Chief Financial Officer Meir Moshe."President Obama even talked about how this is a nationwide challenge following the attack on Sony, which he said came in from North Korea," Moshe told IBD in a phone interview from his Tel Aviv office. "Companies need to be protected against cybersecurity attacks, and so we've seen an acceleration of growth in this market."Radware's technology is designed to recognize potential threats in a network's traffic and block them before they have a chance to do any damage, Moshe says. That requires sophisticated gear that can analyze anomalies in traffic so that "only legitimate traffic" flows into the network.One such product, a new version of Radware's DefensePro platform, was launched this month. It is designed to help high-end cloud service providers mitigate sophisticated attacks by providing more security capacity."Security in the cloud is our main focus for 2015," Moshe said. "We have put a lot of resources into this because it is a very high-demand and growing market."Analysts likewise have a bullish outlook on the cybersecurity market, as well as Radware's growth opportunities in it.New ServicesIn a research note, Imperial Capital analyst Michael Kim said he anticipates "continued strong growth driven by increasing demand" for Radware's security solutions."We see particular opportunities for broadening deployments of application security and data center protection solutions, with potential upside from new cloud security services — e.g., managed attack mitigation and web application firewall," Kim noted.Buckingham Research analyst Rohit Chopra calls Radware "one of the most compelling hybrid ways to play strong secular trends in security."He expects Radware to increase R&D; and other spending as a way to capture new cybersecurity opportunities as well as prepare for a new partnership with a still-unnamed original equipment manufacturer (OEM) that Chopra says will likely be a "large networking provider."Partnership PlanningMoshe would not divulge the name of the OEM, though he did confirm that the OEM will be identified during the second quarter and that revenue from the relationship will start coming in during the second half of the year.Financially, Radware continues to bounce back from a sluggish 2013, when it reported lower earnings and only a slight increase in sales. Part of the problem then was fierce competition that drove down prices, Moshe says.Thanks to a bigger emphasis on higher-margin security products, Radware has now posted four straight quarters of double-digit sales and earnings growth, the first time that's happened since 2012.On Jan. 28, Radware reported fourth-quarter earnings of 28 cents a share, up from 22 cents a year earlier and a penny above the consensus view of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue climbed 15% to $61 million, also slightly above estimates.The company's operating margins expanded to 22% at the end of 2014 from 14% at the end of the year.Radware's stock price sank 12% to 19.72 after it guided Q1 sales and earnings at the low end of analyst expectations. Shares have since regained some ground and currently trade near 22.For the full year, Radware's EPS grew 25% to 86 cents while revenue climbed 15% to $222 million — the biggest annual top-line gain since 2011.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Radware to increase 2015 earnings by 20% to $1.03 a share and revenue by 12% to $247.9 million."By focusing on high-performance capabilities, tight integration of multiple services and multiple deployment options, Radware is carving out a defensible portion of the application delivery assurance market," D.A. Davidson analyst Mark Kelleher noted in a research report.He reckons Radware's "continued innovation" will let the company "expand its addressable market and maintain mid-teens top-line growth for at least the next three years."Radware has an IBD Composite Rating of 95, factoring in metrics such as earnings growth and stock-price gains. It belongs to IBD's Computer-Networking industry group, which ranks No. 45 in performance among 197 tracked.Radware is the top-rated stock in the group. Other high-rated stocks in the group include QLogic (QLGC), Arista Networks (ANET) and Ruckus Wireless (RKUS).

The health care and technology sectors in the S&P 500 have the highest percentage of companies reporting fourth-quarter earnings above analyst consensus estimates.In the health care sector, 91% of companies have beat the consensus estimates of analysts polled by FactSet Research. The information technology sector was right behind at 88%.The utilities sector leads on revenue beats, at 80%, followed by health care.The largest EPS beat came from Netflix (NFLX), followed by Amazon.com (AMZN) and Marathon Petroleum (MPC) .To date, the market is rewarding upside earnings surprises more than average and punishing downside earnings surprises less than average, FactSet said.Netflix stock jumped 17% after the video services provided reported Q4 earnings on Jan. 20. Amazon stock rose 14% after its earnings report Jan. 29. FactSet puts both companies in its "consumer discretionary" sector.In the information technology sector, Juniper Networks (JNPR) had the best earnings surprise, followed by KLA-Tencor (KLAC) and Electronic Arts (EA).The health care sector overall is reporting the highest earnings growth rate among S&P 500 companies, at 21.4%. Gilead Sciences (GILD) is the largest contributor to earnings growth for the sector.With 391 of the S&P 500 companies having reported December-quarter results, 77% have reported EPS above estimates. That's above the five-year average. The percentage of companies reporting revenue above estimates is 59%, and FactSet says that's slightly below the five-year average.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter: @IBD_BDeagon.
Some stocks hit the ball out of the park while would-be investors gaze longingly from the sidelines.
You don't have to be one of the onlookers. With study, vigilance and proper due diligence, every stock market player can learn to spot leading stocks with the potential to hit a home run.
Regular IBD readers would have noticed Palo Alto Networks (PANW), which has rallied as much as 123% this year, well ahead of its August breakout and subsequent run-up.

Leaderboard subscribers were alerted Feb. 4 as the network security infrastructure products maker was added to the Leaders List. The July 20, 2012, IPO was getting poised to clear a 65.02 buy point in what could be viewed as a long cup-with-handle base.

Palo Alto did so two sessions later in nearly quadruple its usual volume. It leaped 12% (please see a daily chart) that day after the company received a favorable ruling in a patent infringement dispute with Juniper Networks (JNPR).

From there, the stock rose as much as 24% before pulling back to start shaping a new pattern. This time, it carved a double-bottom base with a 72.60 buy point. The stock got moved to the Cut List in early April as it fell sharply below its 10-week line.

It corrected as much as 29% during the second leg down, but found support at its 40-week line. Palo Alto returned to Leaderboard on May 28, a day before gapping up past the entry and soaring 5% in heavy trade.
So investors who missed out on the first breakout could have bought at this opportunity, if they were reading the market columns in the paper and online.

The April 21 IPO Analysis column pointed out Palo Alto may be forming a potential base while testing its 10-week line. The column appears in IBD's Tuesday and Thursday issues in the "Making Money" section.
A May 27 IBD Internet & Technology section article covered an analyst upgrade ahead of its quarterly earnings report.

The company's results after the close May 28 topped views, fueling the stock's May 29 breakout. After an 18% rise, the stock set up a new base, with a breakout past the 85.88 buy point on Aug. 13 (1).

In September, Palo Alto cleared a 102.55 three-weeks-tight buy point (2). It triggered a sell signal the following week, but has quickly recovered and is now up 19% from the entry.Some stocks hit the ball out of the park while would-be investors gaze longingly from the sidelines.You don't have to be one of the onlookers. Aerohive Networks (HIVE) is challenging rivals such as Motorola (MSI), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Juniper Networks (JNPR) in the wireless networking equipment market as use of mobile devices explodes and companies look for better ways to manage usage growth. That was the upshot from a presentation by David Flynn, Aerohive's chief executive, at William Blair & Co.'s annual growth stock conference…

Following a rebound year, F5 Networks touts security products as the main engine that will keep its revenue growing at double-digit rates.One question on Wall Street, though, is whether F5 Networks' (NASDAQ:FFIV) security push will expand from the data center, where F5's application delivery controllers (ADCs) give it the inside track to win add-on business, to corporate firewalls that sit between private networks and the Internet.F5 Networks is the No. 1 seller of ADCs, electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks. It has not been big in firewalls.The so-called perimeter firewall market — the main type of firewall — is about $7 billion a year, says research firm Infonetics. But it's a crowded field, with Check Point Software Technologies (NASDAQ:CHKP), Cisco Systems (NASDAQ:CSCO), Palo Alto Networks (NYSE:PANW) and Juniper Networks (NYSE:JNPR) among the suppliers of firewall security products.Seattle-based F5 Networks says that it's sticking with a focus on data center security as opposed to firewalls, despite speculation otherwise."The perimeter is going away," F5 CEO John McAdam said at the company's annual investor meeting last month. "The cloud is going to change everything. We think being in the data center and understanding applications is a major advantage."Cloud computing enables companies to share business resources with customers and suppliers via the Internet.Protects Against DDoS AttacksF5 in May acquired Defense.Net, a provider of cloud-based security services that help protect websites from large-scale distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks that make servers unavailable to users. In 2013, F5 Networks bought Israel-based Versafe. Its software protects Web applications from malware, fraud and phishing attacks.F5's security-related acquisitions go back to 2004 and likely are not done, analysts say. But F5 Networks has a checkered track record overall with acquisitions. One that never panned out as expected was its 2007 purchase of network storage vendor Acopia Networks."Their M&A strategy appears to be focused on (smaller) tuck-ins, though there is always a possibility of a larger deal," said UBS analyst Amitabh Passi.At F5 Networks' investor day, McAdam said, "We don't have a budget as such for M&A. We have a lot of cash, and we'll use the cash if we think we can basically get technology that's probably on our road map. ... Two areas that we've been more focused on than anything are security, No. 1, and service provider (telecom companies), No. 2."In its fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, F5's revenue rose 17% to $1.73 billion. In the current fiscal year, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters model sales growth of 13% followed by 12% growth in fiscal 2016.McAdam called security "probably our biggest growth driver for the next five years."Some analysts are cautious."While opportunities for F5 in security are encouraging, we think they are already discounted into consensus expectations and reflected in the current evaluation," Frederick Grieb, an analyst at Nomura Securities, wrote in a research report.F5's stock has shot up more than 45% in 2014.Jayson Noland, an analyst at R.W. Baird, said in a research report that F5 is making its name in security. "Our channel discussions are generally positive on F5's security offerings," he wrote, "though the company is not typically considered a primary security supplier."F5's ADCs cost $50,000 to $300,000, depending on how many servers and how much traffic they handle. F5 competes with Citrix Systems (NASDAQ:CTXS), which has a security-related pact with Palo Alto Networks, as well as Radware (NASDAQ:RDWR) and A10 Networks (NYSE:ATEN) .F5 Networks also sells software-based ADCs, or virtual ADCs, that run on low-end servers in data centers rather than on its own hardware. F5 has expanded into data center security by selling software modules from Versafe and Defense.Net that run on its ADCs."F5 seems to be making a push toward more license/subscription revenue with both its core ADC platforms and security," said Barclays analyst Ben Reitzes in a research note.Brent Bracelin, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, this month raised his price target on F5 stock to 163 from 153, "to factor in the company's opportunity to continue expanding its security business in fiscal 2015. Overall, security software that is bundled with ADC appliances has increased to 36% of revenue from 30% last year."In ADC security, F5 competes with Imperva (NYSE:IMPV) and Verizon Communications (NYSE:VZ), which sells a cloud-based Web application firewall.Imperva could be a more formidable rival if it's acquired by the likes of Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ), EMC (NYSE:EMC) or Oracle (NYSE:ORCL), speculates Jonathan Ho, analyst at William Blair."Imperva and F5 are the leaders in data-center web-application firewalls today," Ho told IBD in an email. "The WAF secures Web servers and is a completely different product than a perimeter firewall."He says software modules that provide threat detection capability put F5 Networks in competition with Juniper and Fortinet (NASDAQ:FTNT), more so than Check Point and Palo Alto Networks."While F5 is a newer player, I see them as having distribution advantages since they have a broad (sales) channel, large installed base and established credibility," Ho said. "As a smaller company, Imperva has a sole focus on security and a narrower set of products."

The biggest player in the appliance space is Cisco Systems (CSCO), which started out in the mid-1980s selling routers and other networking gear. As the tech landscape has changed over the years, the San Jose, Calif.-based…
A stronger dollar will rear its head when companies report fourth-quarter earnings, with Apple (AAPL), Google and IBM among those that will be affected.

The rally in the dollar has been driven by the strength of the U.S. economy and expectations for rising interest rates. The big question, though, is how currency weakness in Europe and Japan will factor into Q1 and 2015 guidance on earnings calls, analysts say.

"The decline in the euro, (British) pound and yen is accelerating and is a risk for many companies in Q4 and 2015," said Pacific Crest Securities in a research report late Sunday. "Companies with the most exposure are Priceline (PCLN), Gentex (GNTX), Google (GOOGL) and Harman (HAR) (International)."
Other companies with somewhat less exposure to Europe and Japan include eBay, Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Discovery (DISCA).
According to Pacific Crest, Chinese Internet companies, including Alibaba (BABA), have "essentially zero" currency risk.
The Q4 and 2015 impact of currency fluctuations on Apple, while exposed to Europe, could be mitigated by growing sales in China, says UBS in a research report.

Barclays, in a report in September, warned that a stronger dollar and weaker euro and yen would spell trouble for many U.S. information technology companies. The companies it identified included IBM (IBM), EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).
Cisco Systems (CSCO), F5 Networks (FFIV) and Aruba Networks (ARUN) generate 20%-30% of revenue from Europe/Middle East region, but the majority of their sales are denominated in dollars.
Piper Jaffray, in a report Wednesday, said Akamai Technologies' (AKAM) Q4 earnings will be affected by currency.

"Currency will likely prove to be a (revenue drag), likely leading to Q4 results that are only in line with our and street estimates. Thirty percent of Akamai revenue is international (primarily Europe and Japan); both the euro and the yen have depreciated around 5% since the company provided Q4 guidance," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson.

At Evercore Partners, analyst Jonathan Schildkraut cautions that data center operators such as Digital Realty Trust (DLR) and Equinix (EQIX) as well as Rackspace Hosting (RAX) will be affected by currency fluctuations.

Stocks meandered and ended with small gains on this Veterans Day Tuesday.
The Nasdaq rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up a hair. Volume fell on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Among leading stocks, D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 2% in strong volume after reporting mixed quarterly results. Before the open, the homebuilder reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 45 cents a share, or 3 cents below views. But sales grew 33% to more than $2.4 billion, which topped expectations. The stock cleared a 23.41 buy point from a handle in a double-bottom base Monday.

Lennar (LEN) climbed 2% to its best levels since May 2007. It's now 10% past a 42.07 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. In September, the homebuilder beat views with a 44% increase in Q3 earnings and a 26% rise in sales.
Alibaba (BABA) fell 4%, ending a red hot, six-session win streak. Shares were weak Tuesday despite news that the Chinese e-commerce giant did a record $9.3 billion in transactions on Singles Day.

Alibaba was also on the receiving end of some positive actions by analysts. Oppenheimer started coverage with an outperform rating and 133 price target. And Bank of America/Merrill Lynch raised its price target to 132 from 122.

Juniper Networks (JNPR) tumbled 6% in heavy trading. Aruba Networks' (ARUN) ramp up of a lower-priced, next-generation Wi-Fi product should help the network gear maker improve profit margins amid a changing enterprise market, says Piper Jaffray.

Aruba has a head start in building next-generation 802.11ac Wi-Fi equipment but has been set back in recent quarters by price competition. Piper Jaffray analyst Troy Jensen says Aruba's 205 AP Wi-Fi product, which began shipping in May, targets the low-end 802.11ac market, so Aruba won't need to lower prices on its 225 AP line anymore.
Aruba competes with Cisco Systems (CSCO) and others.

"We believe that the competitive landscape is improving and this should protect margins as they rebound," Jensen said in a research report. "Juniper (Networks) (JNPR), which was a competitor with significant traction in the enterprise market, is now a partner. Second competitors like Motorola and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) are becoming much less relevant in the 802.11ac upgrade cycle, while companies like Ruckus (Wireless) (RKUS) and Aerohive (HIVE) are gaining traction, but in markets that Aruba does less business in."

Aruba's stock is about even in 2014, and was down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Shares of Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT), another Wi-Fi gear maker, are also flat for 2014 after rebounding since early May, after the company announced a stock buyback. Aerohive stock has slipped since its initial public offering in March. Aerohive priced at 10 but is trading near 8.50.

"While Aruba largely tackles the enterprise, Ruckus is focused on (telecom) service providers and SMBs (small- medium-sized businesses), while Aerohive thrives in the (education) K-12, health care and hospitality verticals," Jensen said. "This leaves Cisco as the largest enterprise competitor, which should bring less overall pricing competition and lead the way toward continued share gains."Aruba Networks' (ARUN) ramp up of a lower-priced, next-generation Wi-Fi product should help the network gear maker improve profit margins amid a changing enterprise market, says Piper Jaffray.Aruba has a head start in building next-generation 802.11ac Wi-Fi equipment but has been set back in recent quarters by price competition. Cisco Systems (CSCO) faces difficult product transitions that might enable smaller rivals to gain market share, says Barclays, which downgraded Cisco stock to equal weight from overweight.
Barclays also noted in a research note Tuesday that Cisco has no apparent plans to exit unattractive or non-core businesses.
Cisco stock fell a fraction to 21.45 near midday in the stock market today, but it's down nearly 20% since August and fell 11% in November, after Cisco lowered its outlook.
Barclays analyst Ben Reitzes also lowered his price target on the stock to 23 from 25.

"Given that well over half of Cisco's product revenue comes from routing and switching, we believe execution on large product transitions in both of these segments is critical to a revenue and margin recovery," Reitzes wrote. "We believe revenue and EPS estimates for the next two quarters or so are achievable, with slight upside potential given backlog trends. However ... we are detecting more momentum with emerging, private players and others like Juniper (Networks) (JNPR), F5 Networks (FFIV) and Aruba (Networks) (ARUN)."
Cisco's dividend yield should support shares in the low-20 range, says the Barclays analyst.
Cisco appears unlikely to divest its cable TV set-top box business, says Reitzes. Google (GOOG) last year sold its "Motorola Home" set-top TV business to Arris Group (ARRS) for $2.35 billion.

"It feels like (Cisco) remains particularly committed to its STB business — perhaps its most secularly challenged — given the strategic value to large cable customers that buy other products from Cisco," Reitzes wrote.

RELATED: Aruba Q2 Beats On Market Share Gains Vs. FireEye (FEYE) stock hit a new high Wednesday, supported by a price target increase by FBR Capital Markets.
FBR analyst Daniel Ives raised his price target on the provider of cybersecurity software to 105 from 90.
FireEye stock was up 8.5% to 95.72 in early afternoon trading on the stock market today. Earlier in the session, it hit a record of 96.33.

FireEye makes threat-protection software that business and government customers use to identify and block malware and other threats in emails, files, websites and mobile apps. Its technology is geared toward detecting the latest kinds of cyberattacks.

In the report, Ives referenced "massive growth opportunities on the horizon." He said recent checks with customers, partners and information technology consultants "have been incrementally positive, leaving us encouraged that the combination of FireEye and Mandiant under one roof is making headway in taking significant share as an end-to-end, next-generation security software vendor."

On Jan. 2, FireEye announced the acquisition of security software firm Mandiant for about $1 billion in cash and stock. While FireEye aims to detect malware before a breach occurs, Mandiant's technology analyzes and neutralizes threats after a breach.

The combination of FireEye and Mandiant presents "a serious share gain opportunity" from traditional security vendors that include Juniper Networks (JNPR), Symantec (SYMC) and McAfee, which is owned by Intel (INTC).
FireEye launched its IPO on Sept. 20. Priced at 20 the stock rose 80% on the first day of trading. The stock is up more than 375% from its IPO price.
On Feb. 11, FireEye issued a lower-than-expected Q1 outlook, a surprise to analysts and investors. The stock fell 12% on the news, then rebounded, as IBD reported.
"We think the company's 2014 outlook appears conservative relative to the explosive demand we are seeing in the field," Ives wrote.

Stocks were trading near the high of the day going into the final hour of trading Thursday, but volume was disappointing.
The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were all up 1.2% with volume trailing Wednesday's pace on both exchanges.

In the stock market today, network security firm Palo Alto Networks (PANW) surged 10% and cleared a base after the company received a favorable ruling in a patent infringement dispute with Juniper Networks (JNPR). A trial date is scheduled for Feb. 24, the same day Palo Alto reports earnings.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 38 were up and 12 were down. The big mover was Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), which announced earnings Wednesday evening and a long-term strategic partnership with Coca-Cola (KO). Green Moutnain soared 28% in furious volume.
The market got off to a good start when the Labor Department announced before the open that initial claims for unemployment last week fell more than expected to 331,000.

Disney (DIS) gapped up 5% in huge volume after profit for the latest quarter jumped 32% from a year ago, accelerating for the second quarter in a row. Revenue rose 9%, also picking up for the second straight period.
The stock retook its 50-day moving average and was just 1% off an all-time high.

Auto parts retailer O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) also got a boost from a strong earnings report. It gapped up 9% to a new high in volume that was running about five times higher than normal. Software-defined networking is moving to the big bucks stage.Annual global spending by Internet, telecom and other service providers on SDN systems — where software takes a more prominent role in network management — will soar above $15 billion in 2018, with a compounded annual growth rate above 90%, says a new study.The findings by ACG Research, released last month, track above two separate estimates of SDN spending by the other main buyers of the technology, enterprises.The ACG report is good news for companies moving fast into SDN, including VMware (VMW), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR), as well as a rising number of startups, says Paul Parker-Johnson, ACG's practice leader."Cisco, Juniper, VMware and Alcatel Lucent (ALU), and to some degree even Red Hat (RHT) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), may be players, and it's also going to be a mixture of brand-new companies that have made the transition," he said.In 2018, ACG says, service provider spending on SDN systems will reach $15.6 billion, up from $626 million last year.No other projections of service provider SDN spending could be found, but two outfits have projectted SDN spending by enterprises.Market tracker IDC pegged annual global SDN spending by enterprise companies at $3.7 billion in 2016, while Pacific Crest Securities forecast $2.2 billion in spending that year. The ACG study has service provider SDN spending in 2016 at $3.9 billion, with a 146% jump forecast for 2017 and another 62.5% rise in 2018.Service providers might be the most demanding market because they answer to a wide range of consumer and business customers, says Parker-Johnson. For them, the need for speed is perpetual."There is no observable sign that we are decreasing the amount of applications we want to consume — people want their video when they want it and they want their news when they want it," he said.IDC analyst Rohit Mehra says the projection is higher than he would have expected. Service providers usually lag enterprises "in terms of changing infrastructures and technologies," he said. "If you combine the telecom routers and the switches and the optical and the wireless gear globally, $15 billion sounds a little high to me, but it's not out of the ball park."SDN is billed as providing a more flexible network that can move data faster and more efficiently than before. It requires a combination of hardware and software to be effective, says Parker-Johnson.The vendors pursuing SDN "are providing really elegant software to enable the applications at the controller level, and so a company like Juniper or Cisco is going to be making money off both the software and the hardware," he said.As data and cloud computing explode, service providers need ever faster and more flexible networksAnother challenge for service providers is keeping up with mobile users and apps, Parker-Johnson says. "It's causing the operators to look for ways to scale up their networks," he said.Less Than $1 Billion This YearThe ACG study projects service provider SDN spending at $777 million this year, jumping to $1.67 billion in 2015, $3.9 billion in 2016 and $9.6 billion in 2017.Sales will accelerate as more service providers realize they need to upgrade their hardware to better accommodate SDN software, Parker-Johnson says."The reason the growth is so steep is that the application providers and the Internet service providers not only want to deliver their applications and use this really cool software that is controlling the infrastructure, they are also going to be buying switches and routers that are being evolved so they can work with SDN," he said.Cisco, VMware and Juniper will also be competing with Ericsson (ERIC) and Nokia (NOK) in SDN revenues, says Parker-Johnson. "You have some international firms from a network infrastructure point of view going hard after SDN and network virtualization for mobile infrastructures," he said.Last year, Cisco developed its first SDN hardware and software products and expects to start shipping them soon. Some analysts have said SDN could hurt Cisco, Juniper and other networking hardware makers. Parker-Johnson says the ACG study suggests otherwise.IDC's Mehra says the jury is out until at least 2015. It's too early to expect SDN to become a revenue boon for companies like Cisco and Juniper overnight, he says."Many customers are still in the process of sorting out what SDN means to them, so there is not necessarily hundreds of millions of dollars in deals that Cisco would get for SDN," Mehra said.
Tech stocks pulled Monday's session into mixed terrain near midday as Apple (APPL) rose nearly 2% and Netflix (NFLX) rebounded 4% in heavy trade.
The Nasdaq gained 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2%. The S&P 500 was down 0.1%.
Overall trade remained thinly mixed on the stock market today, up 2% on the Nasdaq and down 8% on the NYSE.

Juniper Networks (JNPR) gapped up to an 8% gain in powerful trade. Hedge fund Elliott Management proposed a number of changes by the maker of network infrastructure gear, including divesting its security and switching operation and buying back as much as $3.5 billion worth of company shares. Elliott reportedly holds a 6.2% stake in the company.
Juniper shares have been climbing since early November. Monday's jump put the stock at its highest market since July 2011.

Scripps Networks (SNI) dived 5% in big trade. The gap-down move followed news reports that the national media network operator had ended discussions regarding a possible takeover bid by Discovery Communications (DISCA). The talks reach a level of considering terms or a price, according to the Wall Street Journal.
Discovery shares were down 1%.
Leading stocks on the IBD 50 list strengthened early gains, with Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) and Qiwi (QIWI) up more than 5% each.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) pounded out a 4% gain, taking a new high in hefty trade. The Ireland-based drugmaker announced it was acquiring Aerial BioPharma's experimental narcolepsy drug ADX-N05. Arista Networks, which offers cloud-based switching technology that handles traffic at Internet data centers for companies like Facebook (FB) and Yahoo (YHOO), plans to raise $200 million in an IPO. In an updated regulatory filing, the Santa Clara, Calif.-based company said it plans to offer 5.3 million shares at 36 to 40 apiece, giving it a market cap near $2.6…
THE BUZZ
Cloud computing has fundamentally changed the way companies build data centers and deliver software applications.
Arista Networks (ANET), a leading provider of cloud networking solutions, is tapping into this enthusiasm with an initial public offering scheduled to begin trading Friday.

Cloud-computing centers consist of thousands of servers and storage systems connected by optical-fiber lines, routers and switches that can rapidly distribute software apps and data across the Internet and wireless networks to smartphones, tablets, PCs and other systems.

Businesses large and small are rapidly moving to cloud computing. Amazon (AMZN), eBay (EBAY), Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL), Yahoo (YHOO) and Microsoft (MSFT) pioneered the development of large-scale cloud-data centers in order to meet the growing demands of customers.

"We believe that cloud computing represents a fundamental shift from traditional legacy data centers and that cloud networking is the fastest-growing segment within the data-center switching market," Arista Networks said in its IPO prospectus.
Arista plans to raise $200 million by offering 5.3 million shares at a price range of 36 to 40, giving it a market valuation near $2.7 billion. It will trade on the NYSE with the ticker ANET.
THE COMPANY

Arista Networks manages data traffic at large Internet centers for companies such as Facebook, Yahoo and Comcast (CMCSA). Its technology was initially embraced for high-frequency stock-trading environments, where fast data handling is vital. Then its use was expanded to elsewhere in the financial industry.

Arista's core product consists of a line of ethernet switching modules used to connect servers, storage devices and other components. At the core of its cloud networking platform is Arista's Extensible Operating System, or EOS. The software operating system manages all aspects of the network and enables customers to integrate a wide range of applications and other customized features quickly.
"We believe that our networking technology represents a fundamental advance in networking software," the company said.

Arista has developed strategic relationships with a number of "technology ecosystem participants," including Microsoft, Aruba Networks (ARUN), F5 Networks (FFIV), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Splunk (SPLK) and VMware (VMW) "to allow integration of our cloud networking solutions with their offerings."

Arista competes in the data-center market for ethernet switches that run at per-second speeds from 10 gigabits to 100 gigabits. According to Crehan Research, this market will grow from approximately $6 billion in 2013 to $12 billion in 2017, a 19% compound annual growth rate.

"Arista is a disruptive player in data centers," said Evercore analyst Mark McKechnie. "Arista Networks started with a clean sheet of paper and is clearly disrupting Cisco's (CSCO) incumbent market position in data-center switches."

Arista has 850 full-time employees and more than 2,500 customers, up from 570 at the end of 2010. Customers span a range of industries and include Internet service providers, financial services organizations, government agencies and media and entertainment companies. They include big cloud-service providers such as eBay, Facebook, Microsoft and Yahoo, as well as financial services organizations such as Barclays, Citigroup (C) and Morgan Stanley (MS). One of Arista's largest customers is Microsoft, which accounted for 22% of revenue in 2013.
RISK/CHALLENGES

The market for data-center technology is intensely competitive. Arista's rivals include Juniper Networks (JNPR), Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Cisco Systems. Cisco is the dominant player in the data-switching category, with a market share above 60%.
"Arista found an opportunity to break into Cisco's front yard, but Cisco has them in their sights," McKechnie said.

Arista has a relatively short business history. Its first products shipped in 2008, though most of its revenue growth has occurred since early 2010. The company's 10 largest customers in 2013 accounted for 43% of revenue, up from 39% in 2012.
THE RESULTS

Arista's revenue comes primarily from sales of switching products and software, in addition to its services revenue. Arista revenue rose 87% to $361 million in 2013 from the same period a year earlier. The company reported net income of $42.5 million, up from $21.3 million. For the three-month period ended March 31, Arista reported revenue of $117.2 million, up 91% from the year-earlier period, and net income of $12.3 million. Not including proceeds from the IPO, Arista reports having cash and equivalents of $129.5 million.

"The financials look solid for this company, as they have been profitable in the three years leading up to this stock offering — a rarity for tech companies in this day of IPOs," said research firm IPOboutique in a report.
USE OF PROCEEDS

Arista Networks plans to raise $200 million by offering 5.3 million shares at a price range of 36 to 40. The company estimates that net proceeds form the offering will be approximately $182.4 million, or about $210.6 million if the underwriters exercise their over-allotment option in full at an assumed IPO price of 38 per share. It intends to use approximately $23.6 million of the net proceeds to pay down debt and the remaining proceeds for general corporate purposes, including working capital, sales and marketing activities, and product development.
THE MANAGEMENT
Jayshree Ullal
President, chief executive officer

Ullal, 53, served in various management positions at Cisco Systems from 1993 to May 2008. She has also held various positions at Advanced Micro Devices and Fairchild Semiconductor. She holds a B.S. in electrical engineering from San Francisco State University and an M.S. in engineering management from Santa Clara University.
Andy Bechtolsheim
Founder, chief development officer

Bechtolsheim, 58, has served as chairman since 2004 and as Arista's chief development officer since 2009. In 1982, Bechtolsheim co-founded Sun Microsystems. From April 2004 to October 2008, he served as Sun's senior vice president and chief systems architect. He attended the University of Technology Munich and holds an M.S. in computer engineering from Carnegie Mellon University. He was also a doctoral student in electrical engineering and computer science at Stanford University from 1977 to 1982.
Kenneth Duda
Founder, chief technology officer

Duda, 42, has served in various roles at Arista since 2004. He holds B.S. and M.S. degrees in computer science and electrical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University.
Arista Networks
Santa Clara, Calif.
Arista.com
Lead underwriters:
Morgan Stanley, Citigroup
Offering price: 36 to 40
Expected date: June 6

For the three-month period ended March 31, Arista reported revenue of $117.2 million, up 91% from the year-earlier period, and net income of $12.3 million. Not including proceeds from the IPO, Arista reports having cash and equivalents of $129.5 million."The financials look solid for this company, as they have been profitable in the three years leading up to this stock offering — a rarity for tech companies in this day of IPOs," said research firm IPOboutique in a report.USE OF PROCEEDSArista Networks plans to raise $200 million by offering 5.3 million shares at a price range of 36 to 40. The company estimates that net proceeds form the offering will be approximately $182.4 million, or about $210.6 million if the underwriters exercise their over-allotment option in full at an assumed IPO price of 38 per share. It intends to use approximately $23.6 million of the net proceeds to pay down debt and the remaining proceeds for general corporate purposes, including working capital, sales and marketing activities, and product development.THE MANAGEMENTJayshree UllalPresident, chief executive officerUllal, 53, served in various management positions at Cisco Systems from 1993 to May 2008. She has also held various positions at Advanced Micro Devices and Fairchild Semiconductor. She holds a B.S. in electrical engineering from San Francisco State University and an M.S. in engineering management from Santa Clara University.Andy BechtolsheimFounder, chief development officerBechtolsheim, 58, has served as chairman since 2004 and as Arista's chief development officer since 2009. In 1982, Bechtolsheim co-founded Sun Microsystems. From April 2004 to October 2008, he served as Sun's senior vice president and chief systems architect. He attended the University of Technology Munich and holds an M.S. in computer engineering from Carnegie Mellon University. He was also a doctoral student in electrical engineering and computer science at Stanford University from 1977 to 1982.Kenneth DudaFounder, chief technology officerDuda, 42, has served in various roles at Arista since 2004. He holds B.S. and M.S. degrees in computer science and electrical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University.Arista NetworksSanta Clara, Calif.(408) 547-5500Arista.comLead underwriters:Morgan Stanley, CitigroupOffering price: 36 to 40Expected date: June 6Ticker: ANET
July 2012 new issue Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) is close to shaping a new buy setup.

The stock has consolidated for nearly five weeks and corrected a little less than 15%, which makes for a possible flat base. Barring any wild price action, a flat base would be completed at the end of Friday. Palo Alto's pattern would also be a first-stage base, which is a plus. Early-stage bases such as first or second stage are preferable to late-stage structures.

Palo Alto's prior base corrected 29% and had some wide-and-loose price bars. The stock still managed to climb 18% past a 72.60 buy point by the end of June. But it erased that move by July 8, marking a sell signal.

Palo Alto saw some high-volume drops as it retreated early on from its record high in June, but turnover on down days has all been below average since. The stock has also found support at its 50-day line.
At the end of the second quarter, 424 funds owned Palo Alto shares, up from 255 in the third quarter of 2013.
Leading mutual funds such as Fidelity Contrafund and T. Rowe Price New Horizons owned shares. The latter even added to its position.

Santa Clara, Calif.-based Palo Alto Networks offers network-security products used by enterprises, service providers and government entities to protect against viruses, malware and other cyberthreats. It also offers subscription services for threat detection and prevention, Web filtering and security for mobile devices.
It competitors include Juniper Networks (JNPR), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Fortinet (FTNT) and Check Point Software (CHKP).
Palo Alto lost money from fiscal 2008 to 2011 (ended in July), but turned profitable the next two years. It earned 22 cents a share in fiscal 2012 and 25 cents last year.

While many companies have already reported their latest quarterly results, Palo Alto's fiscal Q4 figures are due Sept. 9 after the market's close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 83% to 11 cents a share. Sales are slated to jump 43% to $161.28 million. The company's full-year earnings for fiscal 2014 are slated to jump 60% to 40 cents a share.

For the next fiscal year, profit is expected to jump 65% to 66 cents a share. Nomura Securities upgraded Palo Alto Networks to a buy rating ahead of its quarterly earnings, due after the market close Wednesday.
Nomura analyst Frederick Grieb on Tuesday upgraded Palo Alto Networks (PANW) stock from neutral, and hiked his price target to 80 from 68.
Palo Alto Networks stock was up 3%, near 69, in midday trading in the stock market today.

"We continue to view Palo Alto as one of the best-positioned vendors in the network-security space," Grieb wrote in a research note. "The company has product offerings that are consistently well rated in our checks and has shown a consistent ability to take share."

Palo Alto Networks, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is a leading developer of next-generation technology used to protect company networks from virus attacks, malware and other security breaches. Its platform includes network firewall software and appliances. It has more than 16,000 customers and sees a market opportunity of $15.8 billion this year, growing to $19.5 billion in 2017.
Its rivals include FireEye (FEYE), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Fortinet (FTNT).
The company will report earnings for its fiscal third quarter ended April 30.

The consensus revenue estimate among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is $146.2 million. That would be up 44% from the year-earlier quarter, continuing a string of double- and triple-digit growth going back more than 17 quarters.
Earnings per share minus items are expected to rise 67% to 10 cents.
Grieb had a neutral rating on Palo Alto Networks in part due to a lawsuit that the company has faced against Juniper Networks (JNPR).

Juniper had filed a lawsuit against Palo Alto in December 2011, claiming that Palo Alto's products infringed six Juniper patents. In early March, U.S. District Court Judge Sue Robinson declared a mistrial in the case.

"While previously, the persistent overhang of the Juniper lawsuit has kept us on the sidelines with a neutral rating, we are updating our analysis of the risk associated with this lawsuit, as recent announcements from Juniper suggest that the company (and its management team) are incentivized to settle, rather than continue this lawsuit, which is costing the company millions of dollars in additional G&A expense per quarter," Grieb wrote.
Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.

Security firm Palo Alto Networks posted fiscal Q3 earnings late Wednesday that exceeded expectations, as did its Q4 outlook, sending shares rising 10% after hours.The company also announced that it had settled its three-year patent dispute with Juniper Networks (JNPR) and ended all litigation.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) ended the quarter with more than 17,000 customers, up from 16,000 in fiscal Q2 and marking its highest customer-acquisition rate ever, company CEO Mark McLaughlin said in a conference call with analysts."We are winning customers because our platform is disruptive," McLaughlin said on the call. "The enterprise security market has been changing rapidly in the last few years, with the number of sophisticated attacks showing a lasting and growing phenomenon."For the quarter ended April 30, revenue rose 49% from the year-earlier quarter to $150.7 million, beating the $146.2 million consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.The company reported earnings per share minus items of 11 cents, up 83% and beating analyst views by a penny.Under the terms of the legal settlement, Palo Alto Networks will make a one-time payment to Juniper of $75 million in cash and $100 million in shares of common stock and warrants to purchase common stock.March MistrialJuniper had filed suit in December 2011, claiming Palo Alto Networks' products infringed on six Juniper patents. In March, U.S. District Court Judge Sue Robinson declared a mistrial in the case.Based in Santa Clara, Calif., Palo Alto Networks is a leading developer of next-generation technology used to protect company networks from virus attacks, malware and other security breaches. Its products include network firewall software and appliances. It also offers subscription services for threat detection and prevention, URL filtering, and mobile device security.Palo Alto's stock slipped a bit in Wednesday's regular session to 69.51, 14% off its all-time high of 80.84, reached on March 18.Investor expectations have been high for a company that pioneered next-generation firewall security protection in reaction to businesses' and employees' increasingly using applications available via the Internet cloud, making corporate networks more vulnerable.Its rivals include FireEye (FEYE), Checkpoint Software (CHKP), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Fortinet (FTNT).The company guided revenue for the current quarter at $158 million to $162 million, up 42% at the midpoint and above the consensus estimate of $158.4 million.It expects earnings per share minus items of 10 or 11 cents. Analysts had modeled 10 cents.Q3 billings rose 46% to $193.9 million. Product revenue rose 38% to $84.1 million. Recurring subscription revenue rose 71% to $32 million, and deferred revenue rose 68% to $367.9 million. Both revenues set records.In the quarter, Palo Alto Networks completed its acquisition of Cyvera, a privately held cybersecurity company based in Tel Aviv, Israel, for $200 million in cash and stock. Cyvera has developed technology that aims to protect enterprise users from cyberattacks and threats on any device, across any network. Analysts said Cyvera will expand Palo Alto Networks' total addressable market by $4 billion to $5 billion, on top of its current addressable market of $15 billion to $20 billion.

Stocks were poised for a higher open on this first trading day of November as a round of merger activity offset weak data out of China. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 12 points vs. fair value and S&P 500 futures climbed 2 points.
Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average rallied 23 points.
Stocks rallied for a fifth straight week last week and closed out the month of October with solid gains.

Over the weekend, China reported lackluster manufacturing data. The preliminary Caixin China manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) came in at 48.3 in October, up from 47.2 in September. But readings under 50 signal contraction. China's official PMI came in at 49.8 in October, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This marked the third straight monthly drop for the world's second largest economy.
Asian stock markets were lower, with the Shanghai composite and Hong Kong's Hang Seng losing 1.7% and 1.2%, respectively. Japan's Nikkei fell 2.1%.
In stock news, several companies announced deals.
TreeHouse Foods (THS) agreed to buy ConAgra Foods' (CAG) private brands business for $2.7 billion in cash. ConAgra shares surged 13% in premarket trading, while TreeHouse shares eased a fraction.

Visa (V) announced that it would acquire Visa Europe in a deal valued at more than $23 billion if certain targets are met. Visa Europe split from its parent company in 2007 before the credit card firm's initial public offering.

Separately, Visa also reported mixed quarterly results. It posted fiscal Q4 earnings of 62 cents a share, up from 55 cents a year ago. But it missed views by a penny. Sales climbed to $3.571 billion, barely edging views for $3.57 billion.
The firm also announced a $5 billion stock buyback program. Visa shares fell about 2% in premarket trading. The stock has had a tough time making progress from a 77.02 entry in a consolidation.

Dyax (DYAX) soared 33% on news that it would be acquired by British drug giant Shire (SHPG) for an initial $5.9 billion, or $37.30 per share, in cash. Shareholder may receive an additional $4 a share, depending on approval for its hereditary angioedema treatment.

Elsewhere, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 4% in premarket trading on news that it closed stores in the Northwest due to an outbreak of E. coli. Shares have already been under pressure recently on weak quarterly earnings.

On the economic front, reports on factory activity from Markit and the Institute for Supply Management will be out at 9:45 a.m. and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Data on construction spending is also due at 10 a.m. ET in the stock market today.

Internet service providers need some techie help dealing with the crushing weight of Big Data, and it increasingly looks like they might have an answer: NFV. Little-known Network Functions Virtualization is a software-based system that can help speed the flow of increasing amounts of data through networks at reduced costs. The biggest networking vendors are vying to be top NFV…

Software Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Functions Virtualization (NFV), two emerging technologies, could help improve the bottom line for telecom companies and other network providers, as competition rises among Huawei Technologies, Cisco Systems and other sellers of those services. That's the upshot of a recent survey, by research firm Current Analysis, of more than 60 service providers. Most say they…

Chip stocks were well represented in Thursday's Stock Spotlight screen. Three of them made the cut, including Cavium Networks (CAVM). The stock has regained its 10-week moving average, as well as a 42.51 buy point from a cup-without-handle base. Cavium initially broke out Feb. 26 and rose as much as 12% before fading. It had undercut its 10-week line a…

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.

Maybe RSA Security should have changed the R in its name to N when referring to its big conference in San Francisco this week.The RSA Security Conference, which wraps up Friday with a keynote delivered by, of all people, Stephen Colbert, has been dominated by discussion of the Edward Snowden revelations regarding the National Security Agency's surveillance activities.Keynote speakers admonished the NSA, attendees debated the topic in the halls of the Moscone Center, and the NSA was the focus of numerous breakout sessions.There might have been even more NSA discussion if not for a grass-roots boycott that resulted from media reports of RSA having created backdoors the NSA could use to crack RSA's encryption technology, which a lot of companies and agencies use.The allegations, first out in a Reuters story in December, led to an unknown number of speakers and attendees opting not to attend the annual conference, one of the biggest in the computer security field.Some critics even organized an alternate one-day event called TrustyCon, slated to be held just down the street from the RSA gathering on Thursday.Mikko Hypponen, chief research officer at security software vendor F-Secure, pulled out of his scheduled session at RSA and instead was slated for a TrustyCon speech titled "The Talk I Was Going to Give at RSA."Transparency ParamountArthur Coviello, RSA's executive chairman, stayed clear of the topic in his opening keynote on Tuesday. The closest he came to mentioning the NSA was a vague, yet telling, comment: "Openness and transparence are paramount."That's not to say RSA, a unit of data storage giant EMC (EMC), hasn't addressed the allegations.In a blog post two days after the first story, the company denied the reports, which also asserted that the RSA had accepted $10 million from the NSA to create the backdoors."RSA, as a security company, never divulges details of customer engagements, but we also categorically state that we have never entered into any contract or engaged in any project with the intention of weakening RSA's products, or introducing potential backdoors into our products for anyone's use," the post read.That denial was made more plausible by RSA's willingness to let the NSA be such a frequent topic at its signature event. It scheduled a lunchtime exploration of the topic by two Washington insiders — Richard Clarke, the former national cyberczar, and Michael Hayden, former CIA director and a principal at the Chertoff Group, an intelligence consulting firm.Clarke, now CEO of cybersecurity advisory firm Good Harbor Security Risk Management, suggested that because of advances in technology, safeguards are needed to prevent a future U.S. president from ramping up surveillance efforts to dangerous levels in the event of another 9/11 massacre."Once you have a police surveillance state in place, you can't go back," Clarke said during the session, held Tuesday.RSA also didn't interfere with the message of Nawaf Bitar, a senior vice president at Juniper Networks (JNPR), who delivered a keynote speech.Bitar used his slot to express anger regarding the NSA's actions and the public's apathy, even taking a shot at those who boycotted the conference."Not showing up to a conference is not (showing) outrage," Bitar said, adding that Americans would express true outrage only if the NSA's actions affected their families or finances. "If the Snowden revelations would have resulted in our tax rates going up to 90%, there would've been rioting in the streets."Such outrage would be misplaced, suggested Hayden during the lunchtime session with Clarke.Hayden, a retired Air Force four-star general, said Americans need to understand that NSA surveillance is necessary to ensure national security in a world with new enemies and new technologies."This is an R-rated movie," Hayden said. "It's for adult nations."
FBN Securities initiated coverage of security software maker FireEye (FEYE) on Monday with an outperform rating, calling its technology leading edge.
FBN analyst Shebly Seyrafi set a price target on FireEye at 65.
FireEye stock was up as much as 4% in early trading Monday, but was flat in early afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 50.40.

FireEye makes software that business and government customers use to identify and block malware and other threats in emails, files, websites and mobile apps. Its technology is geared toward detecting the latest kinds of cyberattacks.
"FireEye has leading-edge security technology that greatly supplements existing security defenses," Seyrafi wrote in the research report.
The Milpitas, Calif.-based company made its initial public offering on Sept. 20. The stock priced at 20 and ended the day up 80%, at 36.
Pacific Crest Securities initiated coverage of FireEye on March 20 with a hold rating.

For the fourth quarter, FireEye reported revenue of $57.3 million, up 81% from the year-earlier quarter. The company posted an operating loss of $61.4 million and remains far from hitting the black. FireEye also lowered expectations for Q1, as IBD reported.

"Unlike most of its key security competitors, FireEye is currently posting large negative losses, and we project this to continue for the next several years," Seyrafi wrote. "We believe that investors will look past these losses as FireEye continues to post impressive growth, but investor sentiment could change if growth slows more than expected."
Risks to FireEye include competition from other competitors that include Cisco Systems (CSCO), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Juniper Networks (JNPR) and Fortinet (FTNT).
Seyrafi said he expects FireEye and Palo Alto Networks to be "key share gainers" in the security market.

Jefferies said in a research report Monday that the risk/reward for the network gear maker is now balanced given current expectations that already discount a strong Q2 performance, the…

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) stock hit an all-time high Monday after the company posted fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue that beat analyst estimates, and it raised guidance on strong demand for its network security products and services.

The company early Monday reported revenue of $141.1 million, up 46% from the year-earlier quarter and above the consensus estimate of $135.6 million by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Earnings per share minus items of 10 cents beat the consensus estimates by a penny, for the quarter ended Jan. 31.
Palo Alto Networks stock was up more than 5%, near 77.50, in midday trading in the stock market today.

The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company is a leader in developing a new generation of technology used to protect company networks from virus attacks, malware and other security breaches. Its platform includes network firewall software and appliances. It also offers subscription services for threat detection and prevention.

Palo Alto Networks is among the new era of network security firms, along with FireEye (FEYE), which are tackling the most advanced forms of threats. Competitors include Check Point Software (CHKP), Juniper Networks (JNPR) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).

"Enterprises around the world are accelerating their investments in security to enable them to improve their business and protect them against the risks stemming from cyberattacks," Palo Alto Networks CEO Mark McLaughlin said in the company's earnings release. "We see evidence of this in continued new customer adoption and rapid expansion of our platform among existing customers."
Palo Alto Networks said product revenue rose 31% to $81 million, ahead of consensus estimates of $78.8 million, while services revenue rose 74% to $60 million, above the consensus of $56.6 million.

For its current fiscal Q3 quarter, the company guided revenue in the range of $143 million-$147 million, above the consensus estimate of $142 million. It expects EPS ex items 10 cents or 11 cents. Analysts estimated 11 cents. It expects revenue this fiscal year to rise 41% to 45%.

"The company is clearly benefiting from an improving spending environment and taking share in the network security market," wrote Gray Powell, an analyst at Wells Fargo Securities, in a research note. He rates the stock outperform.
Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst with FBN Securities, raised his price target on Palo Alto Networks to 90 from 65.
