Earnings per share minus items of 10 cents beat the consensus estimates by a penny, for the quarter ended Jan. 31.Palo Alto Networks stock was up more than 5%, near 77.50, in midday trading in the stock market today.The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company is a leader in developing a new generation of technology used to protect company networks from virus attacks, malware and other security breaches. Its platform includes network firewall software and appliances. It also offers subscription services for threat detection and prevention.Palo Alto Networks is among the new era of network security firms, along with FireEye (FEYE), which are tackling the most advanced forms of threats. Competitors include Check Point Software (CHKP), Juniper Networks (JNPR) and Cisco Systems (CSCO)."Enterprises around the world are accelerating their investments in security to enable them to improve their business and protect them against the risks stemming from cyberattacks," Palo Alto Networks CEO Mark McLaughlin said in the company's earnings release. "We see evidence of this in continued new customer adoption and rapid expansion of our platform among existing customers."Palo Alto Networks said product revenue rose 31% to $81 million, ahead of consensus estimates of $78.8 million, while services revenue rose 74% to $60 million, above the consensus of $56.6 million.For its current fiscal Q3 quarter, the company guided revenue in the range of $143 million-$147 million, above the consensus estimate of $142 million. It expects EPS ex items 10 cents or 11 cents. Analysts estimated 11 cents. It expects revenue this fiscal year to rise 41% to 45%."The company is clearly benefiting from an improving spending environment and taking share in the network security market," wrote Gray Powell, an analyst at Wells Fargo Securities, in a research note. He rates the stock outperform.Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst with FBN Securities, raised his price target on Palo Alto Networks to 90 from 65.Related: FireEye Tempers Expectations With Focus On Growth
F5 Networks is hiring. That's a good sign for a company whose growth slowed markedly in 2013.
The company added 115 new employees in fiscal Q2 and expects to hire another 100-plus this quarter. Many are salespeople.

"We're hiring because we are seeing demand overall as an opportunity," John McAdam, the data center gear maker's CEO, said during a fiscal Q2 earnings call on April 23. "I think you'll see us doing (more hiring) in the future because it would be crazy not to do that."
In the quarter ended March 30, Seattle-based F5 Networks (FFIV) posted its best quarterly revenue growth in two years as sales rose nearly 20% to $420 million.

F5's core business involves Web traffic management. It sells application delivery controllers (ADCs) that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping to speed up websites and communications networks.
"After a weak 2013, the application delivery market appears to be staging a comeback," Citigroup analyst Ehud Gelblum said in a report.

The ADC market was flat in 2013 at almost $1.6 billion, though F5's sales rose 8%, says Citigroup. It estimates that the ADC market will grow 12% on average from 2014 to 2017. F5 holds more than 40% of the market for hardware-based ADCs, analysts say.

While F5 is the biggest maker of ADCs, competition has intensified. Citrix Systems (CTXS) and Riverbed Technology (RVBD) have gained market share selling software-based, or "virtual," ADCs that run on low-end servers in data centers. In the hardware ADC market, F5 also competes with A10 Networks (ATEN), which went public in March, as well as Radware (RDWR).

One big rival, Cisco Systems (CSCO), exited the ADC market in late 2012. While Cisco has steered its customers to Citrix, F5 has offered Cisco customers special deals, including trade-in credits, to buy ADCs.
F5 has also rolled out bigger, more advanced versions of its ADCs. F5's electronic boxes cost from $50,000 to $300,000, depending on how many servers and how much traffic they handle.
"It took a while, but the product cycle appears to be kicking into gear for F5," said RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Sue, who says that replacement of Cisco ADCs boosted F5's fiscal Q2 results.
Acquisitions and F5's push into security software have also helped revive its revenue growth. F5 bundles security and other software with its data-center hardware.

"F5 appears to be crossing over into a next-generation platform with software features that extend into security, mobility and software-defined (networking)," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin said in a report.
F5 has partnered with SDN startup Big Switch Networks.
In fiscal Q2, F5 reported winning major security deals from a large telecom company and a financial services company.

Still, some analysts are cautious, given slowing corporate IT spending. F5's federal government sales are a concern. And while F5 has seemed to gain traction in security, it still has tough rivals in Juniper Networks (JNPR), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Cisco, analysts say.

UBS analyst Amitabh Passi, who has a neutral rating on the stock, forecasts revenue growth as moderate to "low double digits" by fiscal Q4. Nomura analyst Stuart Jeffrey, who also has a neutral rating, expects growth as moderate to "lower teens" in 2015 and 2016.

One worry for IT companies in general and ADC suppliers in particular is that customers such as Facebook (FB) and Google (GOOGL) are building warehouse-sized data centers using their own computing architectures. The Internet companies aim to use low-cost, "white box" servers, open-source software and new technologies such as SDN.

And Internet cloud-data centers have been designed with "in-house load balancing solutions" that direct data traffic to server farms, rather than more costly, branded ADC hardware from F5 and others, Gelblum says.

But F5's push into security could give it a bigger role in data centers as threats mount for government agencies, e-commerce sites and financial services, says Deutsche Bank analyst Brian Modoff.F5 Networks is hiring. Major indices were down again Monday after falling last week on concerns over emerging markets, but Synaptics (SYNA), Juniper Networks (JNPR), GasLog (GLOG) and McKesson (MCK) are all holding or moving higher during the downturn. All four companies are featured on IBD's Bolting Relative Strength Line Screen of Day. Relative Strength measures a stock's performance vs. the benchmark S&P 500.…

Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. For the week, the FTSE 100 tracked toward a 1.9% gain, the Cac-40 was up 1.5% and the DAX showed a 3% gain.Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Stocks were well off their lows at midday Tuesday after a jump in U.S. and European bond yields pointed to higher borrowing costs.

Just over two hours into the session, the Nasdaq was off 0.4%, the S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was running higher compared with the same time Monday.

The major averages were down as much as 1% early in the session after yields on 10-year U.S. and European bonds rose to their highest levels in five months. On Monday, the yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury note surged 13 basis points to 2.28%.
In the stock market today, Gap (GPS) fell 3% in heavy volume after the apparel retailer reported weaker-than-expected April same-store sales.

The Commercial Services-Outsourcing industry group was among the day's worst performing, weighed down by WageWorks' (WAGE) 17% plunge. Stifel Nicolaus cut its price target on the employee benefit provider to 55 from 66. WageWorks is 38% off its 52-week high after sinking below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

On the upside, managed health care stock Humana (HUM) was up 3% in heavy turnover. The stock was hitting resistance at its 50-day moving as it works on a flat base with a 183.15 buy point.Stocks were well off their lows at midday Tuesday after a jump in U.S. and European bond yields pointed to higher borrowing costs.Just over two hours into the session, the Nasdaq was off 0.4%, the S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. The stock cleared a 48.79 cup-base buy point in November but gave back…

Juniper Networks (JNPR) stock fell Wednesday after the network gear maker's Q4 revenue guidance missed expectations, as the company cited federal spending worries. The company late Tuesday said it expects revenue in the current quarter of $1.2 billion to $1.23 billion, up a bit from Q4 2012. Analysts had been expecting $1.23 billion. The router maker expressed concerns about federal…

Buyers were nowhere to be found Friday as major averages extended losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and broad-based NYSE Composite all fell below their 50-day moving averages.The Nasdaq slumped 1.8%, the S&P 500 fell 1.6% and the Dow lost 1.5%. Decliners outnumbered advancers 7-to-1 on the NYSE and Nasdaq. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume tracking 14% higher than Thursday. Nasdaq volume rose 17%.Money continued to flow into bonds. On Thursday, the yield on the 10-year note fell 9 basis points to 2.77%. It fell another 3 basis points today to 2.74%.In the stock market today, leading growth stocks took the hardest hits. Several IBD 50 names plunged below their 50-day moving averages, including Hexcel (HXL),WuXi PharmaTech (WX), 3D Systems (DDD), Yandex (YNDX) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) .On the downside, Align Technology (ALGN) round-tripped an 11% gain from a 58.60 flat base buy point. That's a sell signal for those who bought at the breakout. Shares fell 8%.Elsewhere, China-based JinkoSolar (JKS) plunged below its 50-day moving average after a recent breakout over 34.98. Shares tumbled 11%. It triggered a sell rule today, falling more than 7% past the buy point.OpenText (OTEX) was one of the sole bright spots. Shares gapped up and rose 10% after the software maker reported strong earnings and set a 2-for-1 stock split.Juniper Networks (JNPR) also did well. It gapped up, rising 7% after the company reported profit of 43 cents a share, up 54% from a year ago. Sales rose 12% to $1.27 billion, its first double-digit sales increase in more than two years.No notable earnings reports after the close today, but next week will once again be busy. On Monday, Apple (AAPL) reports after the close. Earnings are seen rising 2% to 14.09 a share with sales up 5% to $57.46 billion. Shares fell 1% ahead of the results.

Friday's launch of two technology IPOs became a story of opposites. Shares of 2U (TWOU), which provides online education services, were up 7% in their debut, but shares of Aerohive Networks (HIVE), which sells a cloud-based mobile networking platform, were down 5% in early afternoon trading in the stock market today. 2U offered 8 million shares at an opening price…

Disciplined Trading: An Investor’s Corner Series
Fifteenth In A Series
Mount Huashan in China has been called the most dangerous hiking trail in the world.
Breathtaking photos on the Internet show hikers on a plank path that's about a foot or two wide. On one side is rock and on the other is air. One slip and it's over.
People who would never consider hiking the Mount Huashan trail will do the equivalent in their portfolios. When a stock rises sharply over many months, at some point it becomes extremely dangerous.
The stock gets "priced for perfection," as old traders say. One little miss can bring a severe reaction.
History's greatest investors have an unshakable rule that helps them avoid this situation. It's called selling on the way up. You don't try to sell at the peak.
Let someone else earn those last few dangerous dollars.
Sometimes, however, you will misjudge the situation. You look at a chart one morning and realize the stock has already peaked.

Often, when a stock comes off a high rather sharply, there will be some minor recovery before it falls further. But it's best to sell immediately. You can't know for sure that the rebound will happen before or after another sharp decline.

In June 1999, Juniper Networks (JNPR) was an initial public offering. The stock sketched a short IPO base and broke out on July 30, 1999 1. These short IPO bases can be bought, but some investors prefer to wait for a conventional base.
Juniper formed a cup-with-handle base and broke out on Oct. 11, 1999 2.
Volume was 64% greater than normal when it cleared the 72.72 buy point.
Near the end of its 330% rise in less than six months, Juniper flashed some sell signals. The stock showed low volume as it made several new highs 3.

What if an investor missed these sell signals? The daily chart shows that in the week ended March 31, 2000 4, Juniper suffered a 6% loss, a 7% loss and a 1% loss — all in fast trade. The stock was now 16% off its high. The disciplined investor — realizing that "sell on the way up" was no longer an option — would've sold immediately.

The stock market closed higher Thursday, although indexes pared gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq, but winners barely edged out losers on the NYSE.
Computer, trucking and financials ranked among the day's top performing sectors. Retail, metals and energy stocks lagged.
A weak forecast sent a chill through homebuilding stocks in the stock market today.

Meritage Homes (MTH) cut its forecast for 2015 earnings, citing rising labor costs, delays in closings and slower-than-expected business in the company's newer markets in the Southeast. The stock fell 9% in heavy trading, to the lowest level since early February.

"There are shortages of skilled labor in many markets as subcontractors struggle to catch up with the increased demand of a continued recovery in homebuilding," said Chairman and CEO Steven J. Hilton. Competition for labor is raising costs and lengthening construction times, his statement added. Bad weather in parts of Texas and Colorado further hurt the company.
The homebuilders' industry group, which has been a market leader, was one of the worst 20 groups Thursday out of 197 that IBD tracks.

One of the day's biggest losers was Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which plunged 16% after the yoga-styled apparel chain guided Q3 and full-year earnings below expectations. Shares fell to the lowest level since December.
Google (GOOGL) rose 1% and shares continued to rise from support at the 50-day moving average. But volume in Google was light.
After the close, shares of action sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) slid after the company announced quarterly results. The stock closed regular trading near a 52-week low.

As software-defined networking emerges, Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD) is positioning for a leadership role.

The maker of data center networking gear is preparing to launch a new version of its SDN product to help large companies better manage their growing volumes of data with less reliance on costly computer hardware. SDN is replacing some tasks done by hardware with software.

Brocade's efforts come as other companies — including Cisco Systems (CSCO), Juniper Networks (JNPR) and VMware (VMW) — are jumping into SDN, or software-designed network, which has joined cloud computing and virtualization software as one of the big drivers of the enterprise software market.
The SDN market is just starting and no one wants to fall behind, says Kelly Herrell, general manager of Brocade's software business unit. "The race here is a grab for market share," he said.
Brocade entered the SDN market with its acquisition of Vyatta in November. Vyatta is a pioneer in SDN and virtualization software, which lets companies run multiple operating systems on one server.
Vyatta Deal Opened Door
Herrell, a co-founder of Vyatta, said the primary targets for its upcoming SDN rollout are telecom companies and providers of cloud software — programs that users access via the Internet "cloud."
"Some of the largest buyers in IT are saying 'We need a different type of solution and we need it now,'" he said.

SDN lets network managers configure hardware automatically rather than manually, thereby making networks more flexible, says Ray Mota, an analyst for ACG Research. "The whole idea of SDN is to have more programmability within the network," he said.
Brocade is looking for growth areas.

Revenue for the company, known for its storage area networking gear, fell by 1% in its fiscal Q2 ended April 27 vs. the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect revenue to fall by 6.6% and 5% in its third and fourth quarters respectively. It reports fiscal Q3 results after the close Tuesday.
Some of Brocade's core markets have underperformed, says Rohit Mehra, an analyst for market tracker IDC.

"They have always traditionally focused on the data center and on strategy networking and areas like the fiber channel (a high-speed networking technology), but that (fiber channel) market has not exploded to the extent that Brocade would have liked," he said.
Moving into SDN could help reverse declining revenue growth, but not overnight, says Mota.
"It's one of those things that is not going to be a quick fix," he said.

By 2016, global sales for SDN will top $3.7 billion, up from just $360 million this year and $81 million last year, says IDC. It's still a small slice of the overall network infrastructure market, which IDC pegs at about $40 billion this year.
IDC notes that 58%, or $2.15 billion, of 2016 SDN sales will be SDN-related hardware, not software per se.
Herrell says SDN software isn't designed to replace hardware.
"What SDN does is at layers above the(network) switching, such as routing and security and load balancing — those things are done in the software now," he said.
Cisco launched its SDN program a year ago. Last month, Cisco CEO John Chambers said the company was late to address the SDN market.
Cisco rival Juniper strengthened its bid on the SDN market by acquiring Contrail Systems, a maker of networking software, for $176 million. It announced the deal in December.
VMware Made Big Bet
VMware might have made the biggest gamble with its acquisition of SDN software maker Nicira for $1 billion last year.
Analysts say Brocade likely will pair its Vyatta SDN software with its network hardware products.
Cisco's SDN software is designed to run only on its own hardware, says ACG's Mota. Not so Brocade.
"Vyatta is agnostic software," he said. "It's not dedicated to a specific device. It can run on any server, so it gives them some flexibility."
The SDN market is wide open, Mota says. "It's a race," he said. "Brocade is at the same starting point as Juniper, Cisco and everybody else."
The SDN market is likely 12 to 18 months from really taking off, says IDC's Mehra.

"If you put aside all of the hype around SDN over the last year or so," he said, "the key is that it's still an early-stage market. It's going to become much bigger."As software-defined networking emerges, Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD) is positioning for a leadership role.The maker of data center networking gear is preparing to launch a new version of its SDN product to help large companies better manage their growing volumes of data with less reliance on costly computer hardware. Palo Alto Networks (PANW) burst into the enterprise network security forefront in July with an initial public offering, with the stock rising 33% on day one.
The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company is a relative newcomer to the field of network security, taking on longtime leaders such as Check Point Software (CHKP) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).
It's disrupted the market by pioneering next-generation firewall technology, says Nir Zuk, chief technology officer and co-founder of Palo Alto Networks.

Companies need next-generation firewalls because businesses and their employees increasingly use external software applications available through the Internet "cloud." This greatly boosts the number of ways cyberattacks gain entry into a business network.
Zuk spoke with IBD about the company, ahead of the firm's quarterly earnings report slated to released after the close Thursday .
IBD: What's the big problem businesses face securing their networks today?

Zuk: In general, your IT (information technology) department knows how to deal with security. They know how to protect you from receiving bad things via email, or accidently sending things you're not supposed to send. They know how to scan incoming traffic for malware, spyware and other viruses.

But the enterprise today wants to let employees use (cloud) applications like Dropbox (for cloud data storage); or SharePoint (for collaboration in cloud); or WebEx, an online conferencing application that allows for file transfers; or apps like Google (GOOG) Gmail and Docs; or even apps like Salesforce.com (CRM), which allows for file sharing.

But businesses don't have the same controls and security for these applications as they have for email. They can scan for viruses but they cannot be sure the file you got via Dropbox has a virus in it. Dropbox is one example of (an app that) makes sharing much simpler and enhances the productivity of the user. These are great applications, but the IT department doesn't know how to secure them.
IBD: And Palo Alto Networks does this with what you call next-generation firewall technology?

Zuk: Yes. The technology is about taking network security and applying it to all the new applications and making them safe to use. Our customers can safely enable the use of many different applications for their employees.

The reason our customers switch from an incumbent security provider to Palo Alto Networks is because they are sick of blocking these applications. They see value in using Dropbox and SharePoint and WebEx and instant messaging within an enterprise.
IBD: Does this require that businesses completely revamp their security system?
Zuk: Yes and no. Large customers don't wake up one morning and throw away everything they have and replace it with Palo Alto Networks. They do it one step at a time.
So maybe in the beginning they replace their corporate firewalls, and then they will have a project to replace their data center firewalls, and then their branch office firewalls.

And sometimes they don't start at the firewall. They may start with an intrusion prevention device or a content filter, and later we become their firewall. But most of the customers, when they start buying our product, set themselves on the path to eventually replace their entire network security infrastructure with Palo Alto Networks.
IBD: Can other security providers do what Palo Alto Networks does?

Zuk: Network security today requires a fundamentally different technology and a complete rewrite of the entire product. Incumbents can't afford to do this because of the innovator's dilemma — if they did (rewrite) they'd be cutting the branch they are sitting on, forcing their customers to switch to a new product. That creates a huge revenue gap for them. Since they cannot really go and rebuild their products, they are trying to modify their existing products as close as possible to Palo Alto Networks.

Our competitors, like Check Point, agree the problem is that all the new applications pose a risk to the enterprise. Their solution is to give you a 'blade' that sits on top of the firewall and blocks these applications. Our solution is we will give you a fundamentally different firewall that secures these applications.

Until our competitors decide to dump their entire product line and come up with a completely and fundamentally new product line, they will be in the mode of trying to convince the customers that a product that blocks applications is what the customer really needs.
IBD: What's the reason for all these attacks on networks? Is it corporate espionage, for financial gain or vendettas?

Zuk: It's all of those. It's corporate and state espionage. More often than not, it's for some kind of financial gain. And the attacks are getting more sophisticated. A lot of money is being pumped into developing these attacks, for financial gain, and more money is coming in.
Though the reasons for the attacks essentially haven't changed in the last 10 years, the techniques have changed. Money is going into developing new methods of attacks.

It is difficult to explain the details, but in general the way these attacks happen is by either directly attacking the data center, or more commonly by attacking an end user inside the company and then using their credentials to jump to the data center and steal or change information.

What's changing is the way those end users are being attacked. In the past, they were attacked via email. Now, a lot of social networking apps are being used to access those users or peer-to-peer apps and Web-based email apps.
IBD: How did you get into this area?

Zuk: I was one of the first employees at Check Point. Before that, I spent a few years in the Israeli military, where I dealt with security-related stuff. At Check Point, I built one of the first commercially viable firewalls in the world, which is technology that Palo Alto Networks is replacing. And I started the first intrusion security prevention system company in the world called OneSecure and sold it to NetScreen, which was, at that time, Check Point's biggest competitor. It ended up being acquired by Juniper Networks for $4 billion.

And then I started Palo Alto Networks. I have been doing this for 20 years. And I have a team that has been following me for many years that is really good at this. It takes time to build expertise in building products like this. I like it. In many areas of networking technology, you follow standards. Here, you follow the bad guys, who are very creative. We have to be very creative as well.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) burst into the enterprise network security forefront in July with an initial public offering, with the stock rising 33% on day one.The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company is a relative newcomer to the field of network security, taking on longtime leaders such as Check Point Software (CHKP) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).It's disrupted the market by pioneering next-generation firewall technology, says Nir Zuk, chief technology officer and co-founder of Palo Alto Networks.Companies need next-generation firewalls because businesses and their employees increasingly use external software applications available through the Internet "cloud." Was Riverbed Technology's (RVBD) forecast for its first quarter more dour than it needed to be?

On Jan. 27 the company, a leading maker of hardware and software appliances designed to speed up and "optimize" the delivery of apps and data via the Internet "cloud" and other wide-area networks, said it expected revenue of $183 million to $187 million, well below analyst views of $197.1 million. And the company forecast per-share profit minus items of 19 cents to 21 cents, as much as 6 cents below analyst estimates of 25 cents.
Investors reacted, as Riverbed shares dropped more than 18% in one day.
"That was a jaw-dropping guidance on a negative side in terms of how conservative they were with Q1," said Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets & Co.
Investors have reconsidered. Shares have recovered from that dive and are up 17% for the year. Shares are flat in early trading Wednesday.

For its first-quarter results due for release after the close on Thursday, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Riverbed to post a profit minus items of 20 cents a share, the same as in Q1 2011. Analysts see revenue rising 14% to $186.4 million.
Ives says Riverbed remains a "prove-me" stock due to concerns over business operations in Europe last year and the Q1 launch of its remote-storage Granite product.
The first quarter is usually Riverbed's weakest. But some of the concern over the company's Q1 performance could be overblown, Ives says.

"We believe the company continues to have low penetration rates, but it actually seemed like a very normal product transition thus far," he said. "From early feedback, we have not seen the level of disruption they were guiding to in a more draconian scenario."

Riverbed's rivals include F5 Networks (FFIV), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR). F5 is slated to report results after the close on Wednesday. Here is our preview.Was Riverbed Technology's (RVBD) forecast for its first quarter more dour than it needed to be?On Jan. 27 the company, a leading maker of hardware and software appliances designed to speed up and "optimize" the delivery of apps and data via the Internet "cloud" and other wide-area networks, said it expected revenue of $183 million to $187 million, well below analyst views of $197.1 million. IBD's Computer Software-Security industry group ranks No. 16 of 197 tracked, on the heels of strong earnings reports. Cisco Systems (CSCO), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Juniper Networks (JNPR) and some other tech vendors got some good news Monday from a report that expects steady growth in the networking equipment market over the next few years.
Global sales of enterprise networking equipment will grow at a compound annual growth rate of 3.61% from 2012 to 2016, says the report released Monday by market tracker Research and Markets.
The report said key drivers for the growth are improved security features that can identify security threats and the increasing use of mobile devices that access the Internet.

"Advances in data networking and increasing demand for smart devices are expected to result in the need for high bandwidth," the company said. "This has created increasing demand for wireless devices and Wi-Fi equipment in enterprises."

William Blair analysts Monday upgraded their rating on Cisco to outperform, or buy, from market perform, saying they "believe the company has emerged from a difficult, soul-searching period significantly leaner, focused, and more self-aware. While Cisco's concentration in the networking and computer infrastructure layers leaves it vulnerable to commoditization longer term from technologies like virtualization and cloud computing, we believe that looming threats to Cisco's business from software-defined networking (SDN) and IT cloud computing models are further out than we originally thought, which gives Cisco time to act."
The analysts also said their supply chain checks "suggest that Cisco's data center portfolio is experiencing strong momentum and that current competition in switching is actually subsiding."
Shares of Cisco, the No. 1 maker of networking gear, were up 1.5% in early trading Monday.

That's an ironic conclusion for a technology nicknamed the "Cisco killer" when it started emerging a couple years ago. Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) stock opened Tuesday up 3.5% after it reported fiscal Q4 revenue late Monday that beat Wall Street expectations, and gave solid guidance.

It's among a bevy of tech security companies that topped expectations in the latest quarter. IBD's Computer Software-Security industry group now ranks No. 12 of 197 groups tracked, up from No. 49 eight weeks ago and No. 68 13 weeks ago.

Palo Alto Networks beat estimates on revenue with $112.4 million, up 49% from the year-earlier quarter, whereas analysts expected $109 million. The maker of next-generation network security products for companies met views for earnings at 6 cents per share minus items for the quarter ended July 31, double a year ago. It gave guidance ahead of analysts' consensus.

"Importantly, the company gave F1Q14 (October) guidance in line with the Street, which we believe was 'good enough' and should be a sigh of relief for investors this morning in light of the company's soft performance/guidance in F3Q," Daniel Ives, an analyst with FBR Capital Markets, wrote in a research report released early Tuesday.

Palo Alto Networks' stock fell 11% three months ago on its disappointing fiscal Q3 report. Shares traded near 48.50 early in the stock market Tuesday, about even with their price after that 11% decline three months ago.

Ives maintained a market perform, or hold, rating on the stock and his price target of 49: "Although we applaud the company's rebound from a soft F3Q performance, we continue to believe that PANW will have challenges going forward and prefer watching this name from the sidelines until it can show meaningful margin expansion with sustained high growth rates ... as we believe competition in the field is heating up with competitors in the network security market."
Yet William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho maintained an outperform, or buy, rating on the company.

"Our long-term thesis regarding the company's market share-gain opportunity remains unchanged," he wrote in a research note Tuesday. "We believe Palo Alto is still a relatively small player with steadily growing influence in the broader network security market, with a large portion of this market expected to transition to next-generation firewalls over the next several years."

In an earnings preview research note last month, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Rob Owens said, "Our checks and earnings results from pure-play network security vendors showed a rebound in Q2, with aggregate product revenue growth accelerating for Check Point (CHKP), Fortinet (FTNT) and Sourcefire (FIRE)." He predicted that Palo Alto would have "the most to gain from a return to solid demand trends as it remains the disruptor in the space."
It grew twice as fast as any other vendor in the calendar first quarter, he notes.

"In fiscal 2013, we grew revenue by 55% and added over 4,800 customers as Palo Alto Networks continues to significantly outpace the competition and cement its position as the global leader in next-generation security," Palo Alto Networks CEO Mark McLaughlin said in the company's earnings release.

On an earnings conference call with analysts Monday afternoon, McLaughlin noted that Palo Alto continued its significant growth rate and should continue to "because we've established ourselves as the clear leader in next-generation security at a time when enterprises, governments and service providers face increasingly more frequent and sophisticated cyberattacks."

These organizations, he said, have "realized that legacy network security technology cannot protect them and, as a result, are switching to cover the networks as their strategic partner in this fight."
Last quarter, Palo Alto Networks introduced a security platform that works with private cloud computing networks for detecting advanced persistent threats.

The company guided its current fiscal Q1 to revenue of $118 million to $122 million, up 37% to 42%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had been modeling $118.8 million. Palo Alto said it would start excluding the impact of intellectual property litigation expenses in its EPS figure, and gave guidance of 7 cents, whereas analysts have been looking for 6 cents. Palo Alto Networks faces a patent infringement lawsuit vs. rival Juniper Networks (JNPR).

Palo Alto rival Sourcefire is in the process of being acquired by Cisco Systems (CSCO). Owens said Cisco "is likely to rip and replace much of its own capability with Sourcefire's." The resulting sales channel disruption "will open the door for other network security vendors to take share, in our view."Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) stock opened Tuesday up 3.5% after it reported fiscal Q4 revenue late Monday that beat Wall Street expectations, and gave solid guidance.It's among a bevy of tech security companies that topped expectations in the latest quarter. IBD's Computer Software-Security industry group now ranks No. 12 of 197 groups tracked, up from No. 49 eight weeks ago and No. 68 13 weeks ago.Palo Alto Networks beat estimates on revenue with $112.4 million, up 49% from the year-earlier quarter, whereas analysts expected $109 million. The maker of next-generation network security products for companies met views for earnings at 6 cents per share minus items for the quarter ended July 31, double a year ago. It gave guidance ahead of analysts' consensus."Importantly, the company gave F1Q14 (October) guidance in line with the Street, which we believe was 'good enough' and should be a sigh of relief for investors this morning in light of the company's soft performance/guidance in F3Q," Daniel Ives, an analyst with FBR Capital Markets, wrote in a research report released early Tuesday.Palo Alto Networks' stock fell 11% three months ago on its disappointing fiscal Q3 report. Just before VMware CEO Pat Gelsinger took the stage Monday for his keynote to open the VMworld user conference, a food truck with the phrase "Take your virtualization to the next level" on its side drove down the street outside.Gelsinger might as well have been delivering his talk from that truck, as its message clearly meshed with what he was imploring VMware (VMW) customers to do."You've created the most resilient infrastructure in the history of computing," Gelsinger told an audience of thousands at the Moscone Center in San Francisco. "And we're just getting started."Not that VMware is alone.The truck was paid for by rival Microsoft (MSFT). In any case, Gelsinger and VMware are doing their best to give customers the technology they need to take their virtualization efforts up a notch.Specifically, VMware is looking to break out of its legacy of providing server virtualization software — a market that's becoming saturated — and extend virtualization to networks and storage resources.Virtualization lets one machine, which typically has been a server, run multiple operating systems, giving it more flexibility and reducing hardware needs.Software-defined networking (SDN) and the software-defined data center, in essence, use software to extend that flexibility in data centers and computer networks.It's a hot trend that networking gear leaders Cisco Systems  (CSCO) and Juniper Networks  (JNPR) are embracing.Along those SDN lines, VMware introduced technology Monday that addresses network and storage virtualization, management of cloud computing resources, and the transition by users to hybrid cloud environments that combine public and private cloud computing resources.The new products, Gelsinger said, will let customers "build the architecture for tomorrow, but also reduce the costs of the infrastructure you have today."It's all part of VMware's vision of the software-defined data center, which consists of virtualized applications, network and storage that are automated using software-based management tools.The ability of VMware to deliver on this concept will be key to its future."A software-defined data center is a bigger problem and bigger market," said Peter Christy, an analyst with consulting firm 451 Research. "The question is whether VMware can maintain its dominant position as this new market develops."The company took a step toward trying to do just that when it bought network-virtualization vendor Nicira last year.But the nearly $1.3 billion cost of that deal, which led to development of the NSX network-virtualization platform that VMware introduced Monday, has worried investors and analysts.Perhaps bigger issues for observers are whether VMware has exhausted its growth potential in the server virtualization market it pioneered and leads, and recent turnover in the executive ranks. Gelsinger took over for Paul Maritz just before last year's VMworld.Dana Gardner, an analyst for Interarbor Solutions, says concerns have been overblown."There was this huge opportunity over the past five to seven years to virtualize server workloads," Gardner said. "When you've virtualized all those servers, and you've saved people all that money and allowed them to do things like business continuity and disaster preparedness with greater flexibility, of course your revenue (growth) is going to slow."VMware can adapt, he says.Investors, though, weren't impressed with Monday's announcements, as VMware shares fell 1.5%.Still, VMware reinforced that it's attacking the software-defined data center.And it says it's already having an impact.Gelsinger brought a panel of big-name customers, such as eBay (EBAY), on stage to share their progress in network virtualization. All cited benefits in the software-defined data center.Sri Shivananda, an eBay executive, said VMware's network virtualization technology has helped the e-commerce giant simplify its infrastructure and gain significant business agility."Software-defined data centers are a reality," he said. is on the line.

Shares for Riverbed Technology (RVBD) were up more than 14% in early trading Friday, after the network equipment maker late Thursday reported Q3 results that soundly beat analyst expectations.
Riverbed reported a per-share profit minus items of 28 cents, 3 cents better than analyst views and up 17% from the year-earlier quarter.
Revenue rose 15% to $218.6 million, where analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $216.7 million.

Riverbed shares have rebounded nearly 90% since hitting a two-year low in July. The company is navigating beyond its position as a maker of wide-area network equipment that helps companies speed up their data exchanges across continents into newer areas including cloud-based computing and network performance management, as IBD has reportedhttp://news.investors.com/technology/101612-629522-riverbed-technology-rebounding-with-diversification.htm.
Thursday's results indicate the transition is taking hold, says Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets, in a report published Friday.

"While the last year has seen many ups and downs, it appears Riverbed has fixed many of its execution issues in the field and is now rising a strong product cycle and nice momentum into Q4 2013 ... ," he wrote. "While the company's product transition has not been fun over the past year for Riverbed and its investors, it was necessary, in our opinion, to further expand Riverbed's addressable market opportunity into its next phase of growth, which now appears to be finally here."
The company's rivals include gear leader Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).

For the current quarter, Riverbed expects EPS minus items of 29 cents, in line with analyst views and up 16%. It also expects revenue of $230 million to $236 million, where analysts were expecting $233.8 million, which would be up 15%.

The prospect of software minimizing the need for hardware has networking leaders Cisco and VMware scrambling to latch onto an emerging technology called software defined networks.

With at least one notable exception, analysts say SDN is no hardware killer. But SDN increasingly looks like a technology that will be widely used to augment computer networks — and that's why Cisco Systems (CSCO) and VMware (VMW) aren't taking any chances.

They so far are the biggest companies jockeying in the SDN market, providing a software architecture that helps companies build and configure networks that can deliver more automation, utilization and programmability.

VMware entered the market last month, saying it would buy SDN vendor Nicira for $1.2 billion. VMware is the No. 1 maker of virtualization software, which lets companies run multiple software programs on one server and which analysts say likely will work in conjunction with SDN.
Cisco's June Rollout
Cisco, the No. 1 maker of networking gear, rolled out its first SDN offering in June.
SDN, a software platform for computer networks, can help companies move and store their data more efficiently, for less cost.
But don't expect SDN to reduce a company's spending on computer network gear, says Rohit Mehra, an analyst for research firm IDC.
"Think of SDN as an abstraction layer above the physical infrastructure," he said. "For anyone to say companies will need less network and ports and that Cisco is in trouble is jumping the gun."
Yet, the fact that Cisco launched its own SDN effort underscores its potential, says Shaw Wu, an analyst for Sterne Agee.
"It makes sense to hedge your bets," he said.

Many companies perceive SDN as another step toward adopting virtualization and cloud computing, says Andre Kindness, an analyst for Forrester Research. Cloud computing lets companies store and access their data in data centers with servers that run virtualization software, which send that data to customers via the Internet.
Virtualization alone isn't able to fully accomplish this goal, Kindness said, "and that's the reason SDN is so hot."

SDN is sort of a glue bringing more cohesion between a company's hardware and software in data center networks, says Mehra. "SDN will bring to the table a high level of programmability and flexibility," he said.
But at least one analyst calls SDN much more disruptive.

VMware buying Nicira is "a game-changing moment that will speed customer adoption of SDN architectures," William Blair analyst Jason Ader wrote in a report last month. He says efficiencies from SDN will allow companies to reduce spending on network gear.

"Incumbent (gear) vendors such as Cisco and Juniper (Juniper Networks (JNPR) have the most to lose from SDN technology," Ader wrote. "The question in our mind is not if SDN will eat into Cisco's core business, but when."
Many observers disagree.

"You're not going to get any real cost savings on hardware by adopting SDN, though that's what some are saying," said Forrester's Kindness. "The reality is there would have to be a lot of investment in hardware to get SDN" to work.

Cisco, set to report earnings late Wednesday, is betting that SDN and virtualization will increase the importance of computer networks, Padmasree Warrior, Cisco's chief technology and strategy officer, wrote in a company blog post this month. She wrote that SDN and virtualization "place more demands on the core infrastructure. ... SDN no more minimizes the underlying infrastructure than a new steering wheel undermines the importance of a new car engine."
Won't Be Left Out
Cisco clearly doesn't want to be on the sidelines if SDN takes off, says Mehra.
"They want to play a role in the software defined network of tomorrow," he said. "They don't want to be relegated to just a provider of the network boxes, switches and routers."

Predictions that a new type of software would steal network gear sales aren't new. The emergence of virtualization software a decade ago sparked similar speculation, says Sterne's Wu. "Obviously, that was very wrong," he said.

As SDN just starts to emerge, a key part, or protocol, has more momentum. OpenFlow is an open standard for network switches and routers. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and others are pushing OpenFlow, and say they'll do the same with SDN.
OpenFlow is just one piece of SDN. The entire SDN market will take years to evolve, Mehra says.

"SDN is going to be much bigger than (OpenFlow) but we don't really know what the other pieces are so we can't really size it," he said. "This is more like a three- to five-year story."The prospect of software minimizing the need for hardware has networking leaders Cisco and VMware scrambling to latch onto an emerging technology called software defined networks.With at least one notable exception, analysts say SDN is no hardware killer. But SDN increasingly looks like a technology that will be widely used to augment computer networks — and that's why Cisco Systems (CSCO) and VMware (VMW) aren't taking any chances.They so far are the biggest companies jockeying in the SDN market, providing a software architecture that helps companies build and configure networks that can deliver more automation, utilization and programmability.VMware entered the market last month, saying it would buy SDN vendor Nicira for $1.2 billion. VMware is the No. 1 maker of virtualization software, which lets companies run multiple software programs on one server and which analysts say likely will work in conjunction with SDN.Cisco's June RolloutCisco, the No. 1 maker of networking gear, rolled out its first SDN offering in June.SDN, a software platform for computer networks, can help companies move and store their data more efficiently, for less cost.But don't expect SDN to reduce a company's spending on computer network gear, says Rohit Mehra, an analyst for research firm IDC."Think of SDN as an abstraction layer above the physical infrastructure," he said. The $85 billion in government spending cuts from its sequester plan will lower U.S. information technology sales, analysts say, but the full impact is unclear.

The cutbacks, which began on March 1, recently pushed Forrester Research analyst Andrew Bartels to cut his forecast on how much money businesses will spend on technology this year in the U.S. by about $10 billion.

The sequester effects also showed up in the results and outlook issued Wednesday by Oracle (ORCL), which missed Wall Street's sales expectations with its guidance for the current quarter. Oracle's profit and sales for its fiscal Q3 ended Feb. 28 also missed views.
Then late Thursday, business software maker Tibco Software (TIBX) reported quarterly results that lagged views, as did its outlook.
"Sequestration will have a negative impact on U.S. tech buying by business and governments, but not a giant one," Bartels told IBD.
He expects U.S. IT spending to rise 6.2% this year, down from his previous estimate of 7.2%. He now expects $829 billion in information technology purchases in the U.S. this year.
"It's likely federal spending on technology will not grow at all," Bartels said.

The Federal government accounts for 9% of spending on information technology, with state and local governments accounting for a similar percentage, he says. Government cutbacks will likely depress growth in the overall business economy as well, he says.
The U.S. accounts for 39% of global IT spending. Bartels expects to slightly lower his global IT spending forecast to a 3% increase — to $2.1 trillion — where he had earlier forecast 3.3% growth.
Software Leads In Spending
Some 26% of that spending will be for software, 20% for computer equipment and 19.4% on consulting and systems integration.

Evidence that the sequester cuts are having an impact surfaced in the conference call Oracle held with analysts after posting quarterly results Wednesday. Oracle, a provider of business software and technology, blamed its weak report largely on an expanding salesforce that needed more training. But it saw other factors.

"It didn't help that the sequester deadline was on the last day of our quarter," Safra Catz, Oracle's chief financial officer and co-president, told analysts on a conference call Wednesday. "That has a little bit of an impact here in North America, but not necessarily anywhere else."
But she also said "our problem was largely sales execution, especially with the new reps."

Oracle executives did not say whether business IT spending overall was hot or cold. When an analyst asked if Oracle was slowed by economic weakness or by a flawed business strategy, Co-President Mark Hurd said neither was the case.
"Anybody can come up with all kinds of factors," Hurd said. "There's always something going on around the world at any given time, and for us we feel good about our ability to execute through it."
Downgrades Due To Transitions

Another traditional bellwether of IT spending, networking gear leader Cisco Systems (CSCO) was downgraded Wednesday by research firm FBR Capital, as was Cisco rival Juniper Networks (JNPR). FBR said Cisco and Juniper will be challenged to offset weaker spending on routing and switching gear as they transition to more software and services sales.
But the problems facing Cisco and Juniper, as with Oracle, do not seem to be slowing IT spending overall. All three companies are facing a tough business transition to cloud computing.
Tibco, as well, didn't blame its disappointing results on slowing IT spending.
Tibco and Oracle, in their conference calls, both indicated product pipelines were solid. Like Oracle, Tibco said its sales teams failed to close some deals.
"While demand for our products and solutions remain strong, execution issues continued to hinder our results," Tibco CEO Vivek Ranadive said in his conference call.

"While it is possible that macro pressures had an impact in select corners of our business, that does not explain this quarter's performance," he said. "Our issues are primarily execution-related, and there remains work in progress on some of the positive changes we instituted beginning last quarter."
Research firm IDC, like Forrester, expects U.S. IT spending to rise 6.2% this year. It says spending rose 6% in 2012.
"We see improving business conditions in a lot of sectors, but not in all," IDC analyst Ted Dangson told IBD.
Spending growth is strongest in the health care sector, followed by business services, he says. Spending on mobile technology is strong as well, but it's below average on PCs and servers, he says.
Bill Whyman, an analyst at International Strategy & Investment, in a report Friday said tech demand is improving at a moderate pace.

"Strong growth in November and December helped to erase earlier weakness and tech is now moving forward in a low-growth environment," Whyman wrote.The $85 billion in government spending cuts from its sequester plan will lower U.S. information technology sales, analysts say, but the full impact is unclear.The cutbacks, which began on March 1, recently pushed Forrester Research analyst Andrew Bartels to cut his forecast on how much money businesses will spend on technology this year in the U.S. by about $10 billion.The sequester effects also showed up in the results and outlook issued Wednesday by Oracle (ORCL), which missed Wall Street's sales expectations with its guidance for the current quarter. He now expects $829 billion in information technology purchases in the U.S. this year."It's likely federal spending on technology will not grow at all," Bartels said.The Federal government accounts for 9% of spending on information technology, with state and local governments accounting for a similar percentage, he says. Government cutbacks will likely depress growth in the overall business economy as well, he says.The U.S. accounts for 39% of global IT spending. Bartels expects to slightly lower his global IT spending forecast to a 3% increase — to $2.1 trillion — where he had earlier forecast 3.3% growth.Software Leads In SpendingSome 26% of that spending will be for software, 20% for computer equipment and 19.4% on consulting and systems integration.Evidence that the sequester cuts are having an impact surfaced in the conference call Oracle held with analysts after posting quarterly results Wednesday. Oracle, a provider of business software and technology, blamed its weak report largely on an expanding salesforce that needed more training. But it saw other factors."It didn't help that the sequester deadline was on the last day of our quarter," Safra Catz, Oracle's chief financial officer and co-president, told analysts on a conference call Wednesday. "That has a little bit of an impact here in North America, but not necessarily anywhere else."But she also said "our problem was largely sales execution, especially with the new reps."Oracle executives did not say whether business IT spending overall was hot or cold. When an analyst asked if Oracle was slowed by economic weakness or by a flawed business strategy, Co-President Mark Hurd said neither was the case."Anybody can come up with all kinds of factors," Hurd said. "There's always something going on around the world at any given time, and for us we feel good about our ability to execute through it."Downgrades Due To TransitionsAnother traditional bellwether of IT spending, networking gear leader Cisco Systems (CSCO) was downgraded Wednesday by research firm FBR Capital, as was Cisco rival Juniper Networks (JNPR). FBR said Cisco and Juniper will be challenged to offset weaker spending on routing and switching gear as they transition to more software and services sales.But the problems facing Cisco and Juniper, as with Oracle, do not seem to be slowing IT spending overall. All three companies are facing a tough business transition to cloud computing.Tibco, as well, didn't blame its disappointing results on slowing IT spending.Tibco and Oracle, in their conference calls, both indicated product pipelines were solid. Like Oracle, Tibco said its sales teams failed to close some deals."While demand for our products and solutions remain strong, execution issues continued to hinder our results," Tibco CEO Vivek Ranadive said in his conference call."While it is possible that macro pressures had an impact in select corners of our business, that does not explain this quarter's performance," he said. "Our issues are primarily execution-related, and there remains work in progress on some of the positive changes we instituted beginning last quarter."Research firm IDC, like Forrester, expects U.S. IT spending to rise 6.2% this year. It says spending rose 6% in 2012."We see improving business conditions in a lot of sectors, but not in all," IDC analyst Ted Dangson told IBD.Spending growth is strongest in the health care sector, followed by business services, he says. Spending on mobile technology is strong as well, but it's below average on PCs and servers, he says.Bill Whyman, an analyst at International Strategy & Investment, in a report Friday said tech demand is improving at a moderate pace."Strong growth in November and December helped to erase earlier weakness and tech is now moving forward in a low-growth environment," Whyman wrote.

Call it a resurgence. Shares of Riverbed Technology (RVBD) were up 28% in afternoon trading on Wednesday after the company surprised the Street with Q2 results that beat on the top and bottom lines. The company late Tuesday also gave a revenue outlook that beat views, and it announced a deal with Juniper Networks (JNPR) that aims to help data…

Shares of Palo Alto Networks (PANW) were down 2% in afternoon trading Friday, one day after the network security company beat estimates for its fiscal second quarter. The company's forecast for the current quarter was in line with views.

Palo Alto Networks makes network security hardware and competes with several larger players in the market including Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR). The company launched its initial public offering on July 20. Shares ended the first day of trading up 26.5% from its $42 offering price. It's now hovering around 60.
In the quarter, Palo Alto Networks reported a per-share profit, minus items, of 5 cents, one penny ahead of analyst estimates, and a penny ahead of its profit in the year-ago quarter.
Revenue jumped by 70% to $96.5 million vs. the year-ago quarter and beat views for $93.3 million.
For its third quarter, Palo Alto Networks said it expects a per-share profit, ex items, of about 5 cents, in line with views but down 2 cents from the year-ago period.
Revenue is expected to be between $100 million and $104 million, up between 52% and 58% from the year-ago period. Analysts had expected revenue of $101.9 million, a growth rate of 55%.

Though Palo Alto's Q2 results were strong, some investors are likely remaining on the sidelines because of the company's conservative forecast for the current quarter, Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets, said in a report Friday.

"While the company posted impressive headline results, management guided in-line with the Street for fiscal Q3, a dynamic we believe will disappoint the bulls this morning, who were hoping for a 'beat and raise' quarter," he wrote. "Nevertheless, given the company's top-line and deferred revenue growth rate (92% year-over-year) in the January quarter, we believe Palo Alto continues to gain share in the overall network security market from larger incumbents (e.g. Cisco, Juniper) while benefitting from more multi-year deal signings."

Riverbed Technology (RVBD) late Thursday reported Q4 profit and sales that edged past analyst expectations, but shares fell sharply.

Riverbed earned 25 cents a share ex items, up 32% vs. a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 24 cents. But it was the third straight quarter of decelerating EPS growth. Revenue rose 23% to $203 million. Analysts predicted $200.8 million. Executives were expected to give an outlook on a conference call with analysts later Thursday.
In early after-hours trading, shares fell nearly 12% after hitting a 6-month intraday high in the regular session.

Fellow networking gear maker Juniper Networks (JNPR), meanwhile, reported that earnings per share minus items fell 33% to 28 cents, as analysts forecast. Sales fell 6% to $1.121 billion, just below the $1.126 billion analysts expected.

But for the current quarter, the company said it expects EPS minus items of 11 cents to 14 cents, below analyst views. And it sees revenue of $960 million to $990 million, where analysts were expecting $1.1 billion.
Shares tumbled 7.5% in late trading.

"While the fourth quarter was softer than we had anticipated primarily due to weak demand from service providers, Juniper delivered record revenues in a year where macroeconomic uncertainty increased as the year unfolded," CEO Kevin Johnson said in a statement. "We are confident in our strategy and our innovation pipeline, and we remain committed to delivering differentiated solutions that are highly relevant to our customers."Riverbed Technology (RVBD) late Thursday reported Q4 profit and sales that edged past analyst expectations, but shares fell sharply.Riverbed earned 25 cents a share ex items, up 32% vs. a year earlier. Losses and volume eased near midday as pared losses in select stocks were turned into mild gains after a tough morning.

The Nasdaq trimmed its loss to 1.1%. The S&P 500 eased to a 0.9% loss and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%. Volume eased from early highs, but continued to trade above Thursday's levels, with the Nasdaq up 25% and NYSE volume 20% higher.

The primary influence on the stock market today has been a soft March payrolls report delivered by the Labor Department before the market open. The disappointing report triggered a sell-off both in the U.S. and Europe.
Losses continued to be broad, with more than 80% of S&P 500 stocks and about 90% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD trading lower near midday.
F5 Networks (FFIV) continued to lead decliners on the S&P 500, falling 19% after a weak fiscal second quarter outlook. Juniper Networks (JNPR) was next in line, with a 5% loss.

SolarWinds (SWI) sunk 6% in very busy action, slicing its 50-day moving average. The developer of network management software had pulled back in soft trade since hitting a fresh high in mid-March. Friday's lowest mark undercut its most recent 57.87 flat base buy point by about 6%.
A few IBD 50 list leaders turned around early losses to post moderate gains.
OpenTable (OPEN), Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI) and Oasis Petroleum (OAS) all climbed slightly more than 1%. All three still hold sizable losses for the week.

Domestic oil and natural gas producers were, in general, bucking Friday's market trend. Cabot Oil & Gas (COG), one of the top producers in the eastern Marcellus shale region, jumped 3% in strong trade. The stock remains down about 1% for the week, but is trading near the high end of the week's trading range and about 3% below a 69.08 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

The company's stock is down 6% this year as the No. 1 maker of computer networking gear continues to struggle with an uncertain global economy. On Monday, analysts polled by…

How will high-growth, smaller network security companies Sourcefire (FIRE) and Fortinet (FTNT) fare in what's been a rough software earnings season? Alarms ringing even in the resilient security niche come from spartan corporate budgeting, troubled telecom clients, falling PC sales, international ennui and plain old deal-timing. After the close Tuesday, Fortinet and Sourcefire report first-quarter results into this uncertain environment.…

Websense's (WBSN) proposed acquisition by private equity firm Vista Equity Partners, announced in late May, is just "the tip of the iceberg" as mergers and acquisitions in the security software sector will heat up, says a report by FBR Capital Markets released on Monday.

"In our opinion, larger technology players such as IBM (IBM), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Juniper Networks (JNPR), Symantec (SYMC) and EMC (EMC) could look to acquire smaller security players to help drive top-line growth/strategic initiatives given the 'high-priority' IT spending nature of the security space," the report said. The report says security software spending by clients is tracking in line in Q2.

FBR says it favors Fortinet (FTNT) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) in the security software market. It says the two firms "continue to leverage their massive installed bases and have experienced improvements in overall deal activity during Q2, with Check Point in particular seeing a better pipeline on high-end deals.

"While it has been a bumpy few quarters for Fortinet, we are seeing stabilization in the field and believe the combination of a healthy enterprise pipeline, modest improvement on the telco front, and reset expectations should make for a smoother road for the company (and its investors) going forward."
Both Fortinet and Check Point fell a fraction in the stock market today.
The firm says the entire security software sector is also benefiting from "healthy secular trends."

The high-capacity Ka-band inflight connectivity service will enable non-stop business communication and high speed in-flight connectivity experience for fliers. Ericsson (ERIC  -  Free Report) has decided to divest its field service business in Sweden to local communication infrastructure firm, Transtema Group, for an undisclosed amount. The transaction is likely to be completed by the third quarter of 2018, subject to mandatory closing conditions and regulatory approvals.The to-be-divested unit — Ericsson Local Services AB (“LSS”) — primarily offers field services and maintenance of fixed and mobile networks in Sweden. With an employee base of around 700, the company has created a niche for itself and is reportedly the market leader in the field services operations market in the country.  Ericsson decided to get rid of such a profitable unit to align its businesses with its corporate strategy of operating networks only on behalf of customers and not selling new standalone field services project on its own. Post divesture, LSS will operate as a legal entity of Transtema, with Ericsson as a minority stakeholder.Ericsson is actively pursuing three main areas, namely core business expansion, targeted growth and cost & efficiency to fuel its growth. The company constantly seeks to seize business opportunities as operators shift toward 4G deployments and prepare grounds for the forthcoming 5G revolution. Ericsson also plans to focus more on software sales and recurring business that complements its thriving Professional Services business in terms of “targeted growth” investments. With such concerted efforts, Ericsson expects to be better-equipped to address the varied needs of its customer segments and capitalize on the market opportunities for faster growth.The company has recorded an average return of 9.4% in the past six months, while the industry declined 0.2%.With a broad proliferation of the Smartphone market and subsequent usage of mobile broadband, user demand for coverage speed and quality has increased in the recent times. In order to maintain superior performance as traffic increases, there is also a continuous need for network tuning and optimization. Ericsson, being one of the premier telecom services providers, is much in demand among operators to expand network coverage and upgrade networks for higher speed and capacity. Notably, Ericsson is the world’s largest supplier of LTE technology with a significant market share and has established a large number of LTE networks worldwide.Therefore, the strategic sale of the field service operations is likely to serve the company in good stead.Ericsson currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). (SEAC  -  Free Report), each carrying a Zacks Rank #2. You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.Juniper has an expected long-term earnings growth rate of 5.7%. It exceeded estimates in each of the trailing four quarters with an average beat of 25.5%.SeaChange International has an expected long-term earnings growth rate of 10%. In the last five trading days, telecom stocks witnessed a sharp rise initially and maintained a flat trajectory thereafter as the Trump administration imposed tariffs on $34 billion worth of imported goods against China. The stocks resumed its ascent later in the week but slipped partially yesterday, as Washington issued a fresh threat to impose additional tariffs against the communist nation.At the stroke of midnight last Friday, the United States implemented its long- publicized trade tariffs against China, prompting a swift retaliation of the same magnitude by the latter. As the battle lines were drawn and shots fired from both sides, the U.S. equity markets remained more or less unfazed by the events and seemingly waited for one of the warring nations to blink first to avert any catastrophic damage. However, after Trump issued threats to impose an additional tariff on $200 billion of goods from China, equity markets became shaky and lost resilience.Amid this cacophony, the U.S. Commerce Department offered a window of opportunity for the initiation of trade-related negotiations with China, as it inked an escrow agreement with ZTE to move it closer to resuming its business activities. This would allow China’s second biggest telecommunications equipment manufacturer to start its normal production schedule with access to U.S. suppliers. The seven-year ban imposed on the beleaguered telecom firm in April would be revoked, post its deposit of $400 million in the escrow account.      Regarding company-specific news, technology collaborations, acquisitions and new investments for network expansion ruled the roost over the last five trading days.Recap of the Week’s Most Important Stories1.    Nokia Corporation (NOK  -  Free Report) inked an agreement with China Mobile Limited to carry out joint research to explore the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning in 5G networks in China.By collaborating with Nokia, China Mobile seeks to establish a laboratory in Hangzhou, China, to develop a demo system that will evaluate the feasibility of newer applications within 5G ecosystem and leverage AI and machine learning capabilities by working in tandem with third parties. This will help both the companies to successfully address the booming market of the digital economy. (Read more: Nokia-China Mobile Partner for AI Research in 5G Networks)2.    T-Mobile US, Inc. AT&T Communications, part of AT&T Inc. (T  -  Free Report) recently announced that it plans to acquire AlienVault to augment its line of cybersecurity products designed for small and medium-sized businesses. AlienVault is a privately held computer security firm based in San Mateo, CA.While both the companies have approved the agreement, the terms of the deal remained undisclosed. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2018, subject to customary closing conditions. Until then, the two will operate independently.AT&T to Benefit From This DealAT&T Communications is made up of AT&T Business, Mobility & Entertainment and Technology & Operations. After the recent merger with Time Warner, it intends to create the best entertainment and communications experiences in the world. The successful integration of AlienVault will allow AT&T to enhance its enterprise-grade security solutions portfolio and offerings to millions of small and medium-sized profit-making organizations.In today’s digital world, businesses need a cyber risk management strategy to minimize their exposure to risks. With AlienVault's threat intelligence expertise, the telecommunications giant will be able to improve its ability to help organizations detect and respond to cybersecurity attacks. AlienVault's innovative technology and security talent will help accelerate AT&T's vision of equipping organizations, regardless of size or industry, with effective cybersecurity solutions.The buyout will synergize AlienVault's expertise with AT&T's cybersecurity solutions portfolio that includes threat detection and prevention as well as response technologies and services. After the acquisition closes, AT&T business customers will be able to access the unified security management platform that helps make organizations more effective at threat detection and response. AlienVault will be a significant part of AT&T’s Edge-to-Edge Intelligence capabilities.However, the addition of AlienVault is not expected to have material effect on AT&T's results. It does not change the company's plans to reduce its net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio to the 2.5 range by the end of the first year after the close of the Time Warner deal.AT&T intends to invest in and build on AlienVault’s foundational Unified Security Management platform and Open Threat Exchange as the company integrates AlienVault into its cybersecurity suite of services. The company is also making investments pertaining to advanced threat detection and analysis, threat intelligence and virtualized security functions.Share Price PerformanceIn the past three months, shares of AT&T have lost 7.6% compared with a decline of 0.2% for the industry.Zacks Rank and Stocks to ConsiderAT&T currently has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). (JNPR  -  Free Report). While Comtech and Micron sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), Juniper carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). It beat earnings estimates in each of the trailing four quarters, the average being 5.9%.   Juniper has a long-term earnings growth expectation of 5.7%. Over the last five trading days, telecom stocks initially witnessed a V-shaped recovery on game-changing merger news but later witnessed a sharp fall as concerns over fresh restrictions against Chinese companies intensified fears of an escalating trade war in the telecom domain.The Trump administration is reportedly mulling to introduce an executive order that could raise the bar for federal agencies to buy or sell products from Chinese technology firms, citing national security issues. The bone of contention stems from an innate desire between the two warring nations to claim dominance in cutting-edge technologies and the next generation of wireless services. The Pentagon has also banned the sale of smartphones from ZTE and Huawei — two of China’s leading technology brands — from all military establishments.Regarding company-specific news, earnings of major telecom companies ruled the roost. The industry’s earnings in general appear to be on strong footing backed by healthy growth dynamics thanks to the existing secular trends in cloud computing, artificial intelligence and Big Data.Recap of the Week’s Most Important Stories1.    Nokia Corporation’s (NOK  -  Free Report) first-quarter 2018 earnings (non-IFRS) per share of €0.02 or 2 cents missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 3 cents.
